Posted: September 9, 2014
												I came in to this game as a heavy Elder Scrolls/Open Environment RPG player.That said, the limited environment as long as it's expected. Didn't limit my experience.I actually enjoyed the more confined setting as a nice change of pace.The graphics may not hold up today to some, but to me they are above passable.The combat I would say is the weakest link in this game.I was put in to situations where NPCs would spam stun techniques which would lead me getting multi-hit and multi-stunned with out me even being able to give a simple movement command in response. Allowing a very frustrating experience.Aside from this, which seemed to only happen against the Rock Trolls or larger enemies that used AoE the coimbat though limited and repetitive managed to keep my interest.I am a huge fan of stories in games, and this story seemed a bit sterotypical and generic for a RPG.Yet it kept my interest with the townsfolk around me commenting on my recent quests I have achieved/completed.I would say this is for any RPG fan for a quick play through, or if you want another average to above average RPG to dive in to. I will say this is worth the 10$ price tag, but I would wait for a sale for a extra pick up, rather than a main purchase. If you were to do that, as I did. You may be pleasently surprised with this game. 7/10

content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												Fable - The Lost Chapters is one of the best games I have ever had the pleasure to play, and I have played many many games I don't have many hours in the account but I've replayed it at least 3 times needless to say it's loads of fun and very addicting.The game has a great story with good plot twists. The player (You) follows the life story of a little boy who loses everything and is taken in as a student of a Hero school then you can choose to live his childhood or not and that's all i'm giving out! Not gonna spoil the fun :)The world itself is responsive to what you do and the Npc's react to what you have done, if you have been good they will be warm towards you, and you'l get a circle above your head like if you were an Angel, If you have been doing bad deeds ( like me) such as hiting people with sticks, kicking chickens etc XD, you'l grow horns and people will fear you and be cold towards you. But that can also be influenced by what type of armor you are wearing, some types of armor have an "evil look" to them  causing people to be repulsed by it. Another fact about the world is that it is not fully open world it's region locked, little areas where you can explore and that's a minus in the game, but considering it's age it's not something the developers could do about it. There is fast travel areas in the hero school where you will receive numerous quests and where you can upgrade your character.You can also buy titles such as "The Chicken chaser!", "Sabre" and many others that I can't remember right now hehe.You can customize your character by finding cards of tatoos, beards or haircuts in chests you find in the world. There are doors guarded by Old men faces that provide the player challenges some are to get a kill streak or getting fat, and as you complete the challenge you will be able to enter the big doors and a chest will be found with loot inside it. There are tons of things to do in this amazing world.The Ending is one that will stick with you, the way it ends is choosen by you, I found the Good ending more satisfying than the evil ending. It is a great game and if you don't have it yet or have money left over during steam sales give it a go. You won't regret it :)I give this game an 8/10 Very good game!!

Posted: August 24, 2013
												Fable - The Lost Chapters is truly one of the best RPGs ever. It covers and AMAZING story, alongside a bunch of really nice side-quests. Basically, you start the game as a young boy who dreams of greatness and you continue your journey through the vast land of Albion. Step by step you grow to be stronger, faster, smarter, and also older. Either you choose to be a mage, a warrior, or a rogue, you will end up to be the greatest hero of all, a Legend. Now, the game has nice graphics (even though it was released in 2005 for PC), an AMAZING soundtrack, and one of the best, and most memorable voice actings ever. The worst thing about this game series is that they have failed to make the other Fable titles like this one.10/10

content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
												So I've decided on making a review on this game in writing for now, but I plan on making a video review in the future. Fable The Lost Chapters has been my second favorite game since it was released as just "fable" back in 2004. Upon hearing about The Lost Chapters I got extremely excited. Hell, I played through the game again on the xbox just so I could play through the second part of the game. I feel that they could have included The Lost Chapters in the game itself and honestly it's stupid that they didn't. But nostalgia blinds me from being mad at that. So I feel that the game plays just as good if not better than the xbox version, but I still wish I could use a 360 controller on the pc port of the game. I prefer the comfort of a controller with games like this and other rpgs because I can relax and actually play the game.The story in this game is a bit lacking and I could kind of tell even as a 14 year old how things were going to play out. I won't be covering the story because I recommend you play it yourself. But basically who you think is dead isn't and who you think is good isn't as well.Fable wasn't exactly a well recieved series, Fable 2 never came to pc so I never really got the chance to play it through, and Fable 3... Well. I think it's trash to say the least.They really hyped up the good and evil system in this game, and for good reason! They were pretty much the pioneers of alignment choices with Knights of the old republic just a year or so before. We have games like this to thank for the big aligment based games such as Mass Effect and Fallout, so next time you say the fable series is awful, it may be bad to you, but they did certainly try to do something different. Games like Final Fantasy don't really have good or evil choices, you're the chosen hero. This game lets you be the bad guy. Wether it's you killing traders, or your own family, it doesn't matter. Also there's a brothel you can take over and  bang chicks for free. 19/10Rest in peace Lionhead.

												I have a lot of nostalgia for this game. It is a delightful little hack and slash, though it REALLY has not aged well. I give it a thumbs up, because it is a good game, but I would argue that the simplicity of it and teeth-grinding voice-acting can wear on even the biggest fans. I disliked its sequels, and I never feel the need to revisit it - but Fable will always hold a place in my heart as a rare Gem from Moleneux.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												okay for those who dont want the long run. this game is awesome. with that odd british humor i personally love, a cool (though cliched) story line. the art-style is awesome. but with an odd camera and a bit clunky combat it isnt the best in the world.but DEFINITELY pick this game up, i can simply spend hours and hours on this game, and once you get the hang of the combat it really isnt that bad. with extra tricks and so on, its quite nice to try and figure out these techniques to be better and so on so forth.although the renowned good/bad system isnt at all what it was hyped to be, its still a nice feature, and there are alot of choices which influense what character you are trying to build, and although it doesnt impact the game much more than the occasional cheering/buuing its still nice, and since it doesnt influence the game too much, i cant really complain since its just a thing you can care about if you want to, its an option, not a requirementthe quests are great, although not very special, this is one of the few games where i can actually care about the side quests.the bosses, although way too few, they can be quite fun, the wasp queen is quite nice and  Jack of Blades 	 is an amasing boss. when i say amasing though, i mean i enjoyed it quite alot.so all in all, its an amasing game, with its querks, its far from the best, i enjoy it to hell, and i hope you will too, since this is a game i believe everyone should pick up at some point.

												My Fable franchise experience was a little bit weird. I started by playing the newest ones instead of the first game....I started by playing Fable 3 and loved it, every single aspect of the game. Then on the xbox i tried Fable 2 and guess what...I thought it was just simple amazing, I looked back at Fable 3 and saw it was just lacking some things comparing to Fable 2.This year my brother said: "Try Fable The Lost Chapters and you will look back at Fable 2 and 3 and see how much they are lacking compared to this one" and soo I ended up cracking it and later buying it on steam.....I ended up falling in love and now i think how much my brother was right, compared to the other two I just  felt like this one had much more too give.Long Store Short:Just buy the game!

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												Music 7/10- This game has a good soundtrack. Lots of memorable songs that help to describe the tension or calmness of a situation that the game places you in.Gameplay 7/10- I got this game on the original Xbox, I loved the game then and I still do now, BUT there isn't much of a challenge to some of the major fights in the game. It might be that certain character builds are just TOO strong for the game or mabey I just played the game too much to even remember if it ever was difficult. Story 9/10- The original game had a great story, one that starts off simple and slowly builds to the main character finding out about his family and it's secrets. This game also gives you the choice to either be a hero or a villian and decide the fate of Albion and its people. Overall - Great game, if you're a fan of adventure rpgs then this game is a must buy. The game isn't too long but it is a fun game. However be warned that this game does have some minor bugs, for example on the final boss there is a choice you can make and it doesnt display the options, or in some parts the subtitles are shown but no dialoge is heard from the voice actors.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2013
												Pros:+Uniqueness from a lot of other RPG's during it's time; naming Karma and Stats+Smooth handling and mechanics work well+Rewarding feeling throughout the game; the choices I made, made me feel goodCons:-Sometimes hard to understand: hidden meanings lie in between everything-Difficult "forces" in the game; killing bandits make me good, but I wanna be neutral-Underwhelming short; for a "your own story" game to last only a few sittings? BleghOverall: 7.0/10Fable is a hard beast to understand at some points, you'll be going through the game and always feeling like you're getting♥♥♥♥♥♥done, but whether you're getting♥♥♥♥♥♥done for yourself, or just for the game's sakes is up for debate. This doesn't mean that you feel empty during it, killing the big figurehead and not killing the big figurehead makes me reflect upon it, and the game will at some points too.The "forces" of the game suffer as well, much like an issue I had with Fallout, being that you killed bandits or Ceaser's Legion, the pure fact that all that I did was just coincidental to trying to survive, I now pay the price by having forced upon me good karma, in this game, good luck achieving neutral status anywhere in the game, it'll take some work. The game is short, way too short considering The Lost Chapters was an update of the old game to make it longer, you can beat it in a few sittings if you're determined, and that's with consideration of secondary quests and♥♥♥♥♥♥ Personal pet peeves always ranging along with the Demon Door's as well, perhaps that was their point but trying to unlock all of them just makes you feel like a tool.Don't get me wrong, it's a super cool game, I'd expect nothing less from Lionhead - the gods of Karma Games. But it can certainly feel pushed onto you sometimes.

												Great fantasy story. You can choose between good and evil deeds. Customise your character with haircut, beard, mustache and tatoo to be scary or attractive. Most of the weapon and armor have both "good" and "evil" variation to better fit your Hero. Character will age with each learned ability. Also you can get combat scars. Unfortunately, make this game work on modern systems is a pain. Anniversary edition solved that problem.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												Music 7/10- This game has a good soundtrack. Lots of memorable songs that help to describe the tension or calmness of a situation that the game places you in.Gameplay 7/10- I got this game on the original Xbox, I loved the game then and I still do now, BUT there isn't much of a challenge to some of the major fights in the game. It might be that certain character builds are just TOO strong for the game or mabey I just played the game too much to even remember if it ever was difficult. Story 9/10- The original game had a great story, one that starts off simple and slowly builds to the main character finding out about his family and it's secrets. This game also gives you the choice to either be a hero or a villian and decide the fate of Albion and its people. Overall - Great game, if you're a fan of adventure rpgs then this game is a must buy. The game isn't too long but it is a fun game. However be warned that this game does have some minor bugs, for example on the final boss there is a choice you can make and it doesnt display the options, or in some parts the subtitles are shown but no dialoge is heard from the voice actors.

												Pretty fun and, if you're replaying the game, it's a real treat. Fable is advertised as the ultimate RPG with a lot of moral decisions and a big world, but those are all lies. It's an action adventure game with a morality system and some mild stats. 7/10.EDIT: Now that Fable: Anniversary has been released, you should probably buy that instead.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2016
												This game is a unique and one of a kind RPG that they developers were never able to recreate in it's sequals. It is really fun however it is exetremely short so if your looking for a game with more then 12 hours of gameplay then this game isn't for you. Also, a lot of music is reused in later parts of the game, which despite Fable's amazing sound track, does get annoying. Also the game is pretty easy considering the fact I can complete it without dying once throughout the playthrough. I still recommend this game, however. This is one of the only games besides GTA where you can randomly kill villagers for no reason, and you do get more gameplay if you try to find all the secrets without looking them up on the internet.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												WHAT CAN I SAY...... This is by far the best of the series, this game is full of magic, revenge and compassion as you start as a young boy waiting to avenge the death of his family.... This game is full of decision making which affect your overall outcome.... will you be a feared hero or a loved one, will you have horns coming out your head or surrounded by butterflys?? It's all up to you.... the story telling is remarkable, the creatures and characters are fantastic, the combat system is very easy to master and not all over the place like League of legends and other magic power inspired games....Once you have finished the storyline, you are free to keep playing and unlocking the other secrets of Albion.... I would still pay $20 for this gem....Warning....be prepared to lose a few days in front of your computer.... If I was to say anything bad, I'd say that the graphics are getting a little old...but that's it!!!Overall I give this game a 10/10...it's a classic and it's just too good!!!

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												One of my first RPGs. It's like most Fables.. It has a beginning, a middle and an end. The rest of it is up to you.Til series got screwed. ( Looking at Fable 3 )Pros:Good, long story (especially with The Lost Chapters)Great villainNice musicGood graphics for it's time.AlbionChoices (Mostly evil and good though)MoralityAgeTattoos (Even custom)Variety of appearanceScars (Come on how is this not a thing in modern games?)Good bossesBooksDecapitationsModsMarriage (Till your wife gets eaten by a Balverine)Sidequests are goodTeleport (No need to walk everywhere.)Better than the remake:Has menu made for PCsCharacters don't look like plastic trashCheaperCons:Lack of red apples.The guardsGrey hair for heroes.The stickBlack roseRestricted explorationEeh combat (not that modern)No voice for player, even though he has a set background.Lip synching (or it's lack of)You can't save during quests.Overall: Old but gold

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												I remember playing this game when I was younger and it was everything I ever dreamed about for a month atleast, back then it seemed like a long journey through the fable world, growing from a young scamp of a hero into a 70 year old bulked up, sword wielding legend. So naturally I jumped for joy when I saw Fable: The Lost Chapters on steam so I could relive the adventure... I completed the game in around 10 hours including the lost chapters section, if you loved or enjoyed the original fable back on Xbox then Im sure you would enjoy this just as much if not more but dont be sad if you complete the game within 2 seconds.Graphics - Good (for its age)Story - Epic (Best one out of all the Fables)Gameplay - Does The Job (for its age)Mechanics - Does The Job (for its age)Memories - Brought BackOverall - For the games age I'd give it a solid 8/10

content:
Posted: January 31, 2013
												Avaliable only on computer, unlike it's follow-ups, this PC game is still as good. My only faults are: that it was made in the dark ages of gaming when nearly all games had male protagonists, so there isn't any female option to play as; and that the people are fairly boring (none of the NPCs have as much character background as those in Fable 2 and 3, and you've no dog as a companion). The NPCs also follow you around with simple interactions and have hearts over their heads to indicate romanceable or not. It's not Fable 3 bad, but it's certainly not as good as Fable 2. Finally, clothing is fairly limited in this game unlike its successors, as the outfits of Knight, bandit, etc, do not have dye options. Plus, it also seems like a carry-on in the series; you're required to attain a bandit outfit from boxes in order to gain entry into the bandits' camp, which is very similar to Fable 3. However, to be fair, in Fable 3 you have the options of dying the outfit and changing your hairstyle more. Plus, you never actually meet any Knights in this game, or in the others for that matter, so that outfit is made practically meaningless. Basically, Fable 1 therefore mostly just has showy outfits for the player.However, if you're a fan and want to find out how it began (I played 3, 2, and then 1), then this would be a good choice. The story-line is interesting, if a tad cliche, with the main character's family being separated by a bandit attack; you still have moral choices (good or bad actions, skinny or tubby, etc); there is certainly more information in Fable 1, as on the menu you can find how many houses you own to whether you're defined as hetro/homosexual through your interactions (information that isn't present in Fable 2 and 3!); you're more likely to gain scars and die during the battles in this one, as the gameplay is more difficult; and the graphics are quite good for a game this old.Further, with the release of Fable 1 Anniversary on xbox360, the graphics are even further improved if you're more inclined to spend a little more and play on the console. The pixels are more noticeably defined on the console, but there are known glitches and the developers didn't add anything to the series. You would literally be spending your money on just lighter graphics. This PC version is just as good. In fact, it's better because it has more of a history.So, all in all, the PC Fable 1: Lost chapters is a good game if you're looking for an intro into playing the later series or you're in want of playing a humorous game (the quests certainly do fit that bill).

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Every time I play Fable I'm pleasantly reminded as to just how timeless it really is. It's so damn good in my opinion that at least every 2 years I find myself playing it again, just to re-experience it and all of its stellar contents. In my opinion it's way up there in what I'd consider one of the best RPG's - if not one of the best games - of all time. If you haven't played it before, buy it and find the time to. You won't regret it if you're interested in good video games. I'll preface in saying that I've played this game far more outside of Steam, on both PC & Xbox, so I've more hours played this than what my profile suggests.The amount of dynamic freedom Fable offers you is unprecedented anywhere else even now. 10 years on, I'm still surprised by how much I'm allowed to do. Infiltrating a bandit camp? You can either shoot the guards to pass, or sneak in-between them. Further in, you then need to retrieve a uniform; which then allows you access to the base camp. But how do you proceed to the Boss's location? You can choose to kill all the bandits in sight, drawing out the elites, opening your passageway. How about you release captive slaves as a diversion, hire a group of assassins to do the work for you, OR acquire a pass from a shady bandit hiding in a dark corner for 1000 gold pieces. Which you can then kill him to retrieve your money. Or just skip giving the part where you pay him. And it doesn't indicate to you these options - it leaves it for you to find them.You've got all of the game's tight mechanics, and then on top of that it shoves this titanic amount of meta-content. Visit bars to play games like Blackjack, Pairs and a table-top golf-esque game called Coin Flick. Assist traders with their passage through the woods, seek out silver keys to open locked chests or pursue a treasure trail. Go fishing. Dig up some loot. ♥♥♥♥ some ♥♥♥♥♥es that you pick up from your nearby Inn. Oh, and CHICKEN KICKING, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. There's just so much to love. The sense of culture is hilarious; the attention to detail, consuming. The story, soundtrack and characters are memorable ones, too, and after finishing The Lost Chapters - the game's rather large and only expansion, from which this edition gets its namesake - for my first time this weekend, I can easily say Jack of Blades is certainly one of the most appealing antagonists I've seen in a video game.I could write about this game for ages. One of the highest recommendations I could give for any video game out.TL;DR: If you are one of the few that haven't played Fable, go out and buy it. It's a ♥♥♥♥ing awesome game. Period.

												It's the best Fable game but that isn't really saying much considering how awful the rest of the games in the series are. The skills you can unlock don't really do much other than look flashy and you're honestly better off just upgrading your stats until you can slash every enemy until it dies.If you haven't played a Fable game, don't go in expecting much because expectations are what killed this game.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
												Fable: The Lost ChaptersFable is one of the first M games I had ever been allowed to play when I was younger, and I believe that even now, it has aged gracefully. In Fable, it is simply astounding to the amount of interactions you can have with people. Sneer at them, scare the crap out of them, and children will run in terror at your approach. Or, become the saint that all love and respect, and give everyone a gift or two. Or, give 'em the middle finger and tell 'em to ♥♥♥♥ off. Then say sorry. Then ask a gay man to marry you. Reputation is everything in this game, be you good or evil, a good reputation for being good or evil is still a necessity. Or, live between the lines, but there are times that playing around with your alignment is not the way to go, and only one choice can be made. That choice, however, is entirely up to you.While the game does not entirely match up to some of the graphics of today, this game looks very beautyful and full of life, or death, especialy for it's time. The gameplay is very simple as well, and combat against multiple enemies can be fun, easy, very action packed once you get used to it. The replay value is actualy suprisingly high for the kind of game it is, and I'll tell you, I played this game on the XBOX dozens of times, each time telling myself I would become a different person, and each time, I found out something new about the game.I will say that if there is anyone out there who wishes to test their fantasy of a Hero or Villian, come along and experience the game that changed the way games were made. 9.5/10

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												NOT CONTROLLER READY! WTF MICROSOFT?! COULDN'T YOU PORT YOUR CONSOL GAME TO THE PC WITH GAMEPAD MAPPING?!?!?!?I have yet to play the pc version, but after finding this out, I am turned off to play Fable: The Lost Chapters for the pc.*EDIT 3/26/2014*So I decided to give Fable a chance and so far playing with a mouse and keyboard is not so bad. Keep in mind though that I just started playing so I have yet to have any combat. I just wanted to say that Key  and Mouse isn't as bad as I thought.*EDIT 3/29/2014So I have been playing Fable: The Lost Chapters for a while and I feel like I must note that the game is great ALTHOUGH I do run into some difficulties due to where the actions are mapped. You might have two actions mapped to the same key, so you end up doing things that would didn't want to do. I thought that it was just me not being used the Keyboard and Mouse, but I still notice that I am getting actions twisted. I just want to make one thing clear thought, this is not game breaking. The game is still as wonderful as i remember. With added content waiting for me to explore, I am anticipating what I am going to encounter next!*EDIT 4/4/2014This will be my final edit for Fable: The Lost Chapters.After playing Fable for like the millionth time (probably 5th time), I have to say that i did enjoy the new content. The Lost Chapters added more to the mythos behind the game and I did feel like I wanted to know more. Something else that The Lost Chapters (TLC in short) gives you is a somewhat better conclusion than the original. Although I feel like they could have done a lot more with this expansion. In a way, it feels like its what the original game SHOULD have been rather than purchasing TLC again in stores.I know than when people first played this game, one of the main complaints was that it was a really short game, but I dont know, I clocked in with my 5th play through at around 18 hours, and im typing this right after I finished the game, no back tracking. Fable has a world that has SO MUCH potential, but the way it presents itself in the game seems as if it was half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ almost as if it was a blast talking about it, but the effort wasn't put into it. The way I see Fable is just a greeting to the world of Albion.Game play on the computer was difficult at fist. I had a lot of trouble getting my character to do what I wanted since some keys are mapped along with other actions, but the issue was resolved when I mapped the magic activation and exp orb gathering to the mouse thumb keys. Remaping my keys made the gameplay a lot better.Fable is a game that is a must play, wether you are new to the series or played the sequels. I recommend when playing this that you take your time, listen to what everyone (with a green glow) has to say. and explore the world.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Fable is a groundbreaking roleplaying-adventure game from Peter Molyneux, in which your every action determines your skills, appearance, and reputation. Create your life story from childhood to death. Grow from an inexperienced adolescent into the most powerful being in the world. Choose the path of righteousness or dedicate your life to evil. Muscles expand with each feat of strength. Force of will increases with each work of wit. Obesity follows gluttony, and skin tans with exposure to sunlight and bleaches bone-white by moonlight. Earn scars in battle and lines of experience with age. Each person you aid, each flower you crush, and each creature you slay will change this world forever. Fable: Who will you be?

												Very good game. You can choose between good and bad. This also changes your skin from godlike with nimbus on your head to devilface with 2 horns on your forehead.If you only follow the mainquests the game is a bit short but if you try all quests and if you play it 2 times (good/bad) it has a moderate playtime.You start the game as kid and you will grow up while playing. Also with skin changing and a growing beard and changing haircolor. Story is good, gameplay is good. Game has a nice moneytrick which seems very planned by the developer.I have played it 2 times for testing both sides and the story really changes a bit, every side has his pros and contras. Check it out yourself. ;D9/10

content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												Now, I'm not one of those people who had this game ruined by the hype that ensued around its release, nor does this game offend me, I'm just voicing what I feel is so problematic with this game. Fable is essentially an action RPG, so I'm going to hold it to my standards of an action RPG, I feel that is only fair. Since Fable is an action RPG I guess I'd be best to start with its RPG elements. My biggest complaint is how shallow they actually are, they make Pokemon (the single player aspect that is, so the fanboys stop ripping my head off) look super in depth and complex. No thought needs to be put into leveling your character to make sure he can face the challenges ahead. The fun of RPG elements is having to make a tough call on what needs to be leveled to keep your character ready for the fights ahead. The thing is you can essentially max out the levels in every skill tree in one playthrough, this lowers replay value significantly, and eliminates the decision making aspect that makes RPG elements so enjoyable. Other action RPGs like Fallout New Vegas have max levels, so you have to making a decision as to what you're actually going to level up, this ensures the player isn't mindlessly filling all the bars on the stats screen, keeps the game interesting. All of the RPG elements are basically tacked on, and have little to do with your success in combat in any way more than how much damage you do, and how much defense you haveSo if the RPG elements are rather shallow, the game must fall back on its action, or combat. The combat in Fable is rather uninteresting to be quite honest. It has little depth to it as well, as it ends up being constantly clicking to keep hitting the enemy in the face, shooting the enemy or blasting an enemy wth some spell. *Correction* Enemies do have weaknesses, but I went the whole game without noticing a real difficulty jump from ignoring these weaknesses, rendering them pointless, since they failed to add complexity to the way I played the game. Enemies don't have stats that effect the damage you do to them, like if they wear armor or are immune to certain spells or elements or weapons. So little thought is required from the player to be successful in combat. The combat is so simple that it grew quite repetitive and monotonous very quickly. An in depth RPG system and nuanced combat would give players something to dig into, invest time in and master, but this game plays more like a really uexciting beat 'em up than an RPG.Of course there is player choice and morality, which has become a near industry standard in action RPGs. Just like the combat and level system, the element of choice is just as simplistic. Most situations have very black and white morality involved, which holds back a players freedom to construct a character that is anything other than a saint or a demon. While you are given choices, you never face serious consequences for these choices, so why should they matter to the player? One choice bothers me in particular, where *SPOILERS* you can choose to put on the mask or not at the end of the game. Instead of using some kind of prompt or better yet presenting this choice to me through the gameplay, the choice happens during a cutscene, and the way they handle it baffles me to no end. Why would you click the mouse to NOT put on the mask? Wouldn't you NOT click the mouse to NOT put on the mask? How is a player supposed to know it isn't just a regular old cutscene, this isn't conveyed to the player on any level.Fable highlights my problem with morality systems in general. Fable tells the player what is right and what is wrong, so the player doesn't have to think about this morality for themselves. The morality system should have been a hidden aspect of the game, working behind the scenes, so the player doesn't know they are being judged on a moral scale. If the player was making morality choices throughout the game without being told which options are good or bad, their actual moral alignment would come to light, and the game would make people think about the decisions they made. But since this game tells you immediately the good and evil options, people will choose what the game tells them is good or bad rather than what they actually believe, this morality system reveals nothing about the player, and has little bearing on the direction the story actually goes. People's true moral standing comes most to light when morality isn't in their thoughts at all. Since the morality system doesn't make me question my moral alignment, or have any serious consequences story wise, why should I care about making these decisions? I make decisions in the real world because I am concerned with their consequences.This game gets a lot of recognition for its charm, I'd credit the game's tone. While the story, characters and setting are not exactly super compelling, especially on RPG standards, the tone is handled quite well. The tone of this game lends Fable a pretty memorable atmosphere. The most prominent example of the game's use of tone is right from the beginning when a light hearted intro is suddenly cast aside by a quite jarring, uncomfortable and expectation flipping tonal shift as tragedy strikes the main character. This intro is a nice kick-off to the game's plot, and gets the player ready to start the game. Unfortunately charm alone can't hold up a game.I feel Fable, while not as offensively simplistic as its sequels, is still too lacking in sophistication on a gameplay standpoint for me to consider it a solid action RPG, and I cannot recommend it to anyone.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												It's taken me about 8 years to get around to it, but I've finally mustered up the desire to beat Fable: The Lost Chapters - and it's taken me around 10 years to beat EITHER version of Fable. It was my first (quasi-)RPG on my first game console; so yes, I do have quite a few fond memories of this game in my youth. Does that mean that this game gets a rose-tinted reccomendation, free from the burden of actual critique? Far from it.In terms of tone and presentation, Fable: The Lost Chapters is unique. It's one of the few fantasy settings in a video game I can think of that doesn't take much influence from Tolken: while some of the more tropey fantasy creatures such as Trolls and Nymphs are present, there are quite a few original creations, too. The artstyle and general world design echoes more traditional fantasy, giving the impression that one is, yes, in a fable. Top that off with tounge-in-cheek writing, a fantastic soundtrack by Russel Shaw, and vocal talent that is evidently from creator company Lionhead Studio's home town of Guildford, England, and Fable feels extremely fresh more than 10 years later. However, the mirror-sheen production values can't hide a game that is, for lack of a better word, pretentious. Every mechanic, encounter, and story element is played up to be grandiose and epic in scale, but after the first few hours, the game clearly is clearly struggling to swim to the deep end of the pool. The game's most notable feature, the morality system, is represented by "good boy" and "bad boy" scale (note: may not actually be what they are called in-game), and the extent of how much the game changes boils down to horns or a halo on your characters head, and wether or not townsfolk run away screaming or endlessly clap their hands above their hands yelling "AAAAAAAAYYYYYYYYYYYYY" (no, seriously). Most good boy points are aquired by saving people from attackers; most bad boy points are acquired by killing every non-combatant in sight. Even during major, story-influencing events, the choices are presented to you in a yes-or-no question asked by the game; the only remnants of what you did afterwards are an entry in your character's journal and villagers straight up telling you exactly what you did a few quests ago. The system is so arbitrary and easily-manipulated that you can go from villian to hero in a couple binary choices' time. Worried about a hard choice? Don't worry, the game will compansate you equally either way, so even if you choose not to do something that would be rewarding, you'll still get an alternative item or money for participating.The combat and leveling don't leave much room for role-playing. You can level up your hero's abilities ad infinitum; sure, you'll specialize at first, but what will you do when you've leveled up your specialities' abilties nearly all the way and have spare expirience to spend on less-leveled abilites? As a result, the game's combat becomes all too easy and boring very quickly, and never compensates for your higher level. The game at least tracks how you play, so it gives you a nice illusion of having your own playstyle by giving you a title based on magic, bow, and sword use. By the game's end, your character will end up the same mary-sue every playthrough save for how many good or bad boy points you've earned and what clothing from the game's extremely limited wardrobe you've chosen to adorn your character with. And the rest of the game is just fluff. You can get married! Except there is very little reason to unless you want to get underpowered weapons gifted to you from time to time. Prices vary between shops, so you can be a buisnessman and buy low and sell high! Except that the price range doesn't change all that much, and by the time you're buying and selling really expensive items you'll be rolling in too much dough for it to matter. You can buy houses and shops and rent them out! Except you make tons more money for completing quests anyway, and you don't have to go out of you way to pick up your reward that way. Maybie my nostalgia goggles are broken, but even after understanding that Fable: The Lost Chapters didn't live up to the hype all those years ago, it still managed to dissapoint me. The whole game felt like it was one big lie that someone was trying desperately to show that it was true. Given the precendence of Lionhead Studios and it's rather hyperbole-prone founder, I guess I shouldn't be too suprised. Well played, Peter.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												It's very short. If you want a good RPG where you can choose to be good or evil, you should prefer knight of the old republic.Thanks to Beagán comment, I explain why I'm saying "It's very short" :Yes, i played it 28h but in fact i tried to compare the good and evil side, so it's more like 2x 14h. And I was very disapointed. If I read again :"Each person you aid, each flower you crush, and each creature you slay will change this world forever" [...] "Create your life story from childhood to death"but it's not very like that, the side you choose is not very important. And there is a big ellipsis from child to adult. So it's not a bad game but since I buyed it for that I feeled like I was lied.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												I am not reviewing this game in the perspective of "at the time it came out" or comparing the editions in any way. I'm reviewing this game as it is, for what it was to me playing it in 2016.TL;DR: I wanted to like this game a lot but overrall I couldn't get over how clumsy it is. I personally cannot recommend it to anyone. I'm sure it was more worth playing at its time, but in 2016 you have so many better RPGs at hand and this is not one of those timeless classics, which I truly thought it would be.To start, the save system is an absolute disaster. You can manually save the game while you play, but when you're in a quest you can "hero save" which saves your items and stats but not your quest progress. In any case, both of them are extremely problematic. It's not actually consistent what saves and what doesn't, and the game is in no way smart about making sure it saves properly. For example, at some point the game forgot that I had completed a side quest, but it remembered that I had used the items required in the quest.... so basically, it made the quest impossible to complete. On a later save, a bunch of my money disappeared but it remembered the things I had bought during that same session. It just picks and chooses what it remembers and what it doesn't, occasionally breaking an entire storyline altogether. This alone is a game breaker.Now to combat. Fighting against one enemy, combat is sort of fun. You lock on to your target, you can hack and roll and block to be a formidable fighter. As soon as 2+ enemies come at you, it all falls apart. Blocking becomes useless (actually, blocking performs inconsistently to begin with). The target system is supposed to let you switch between targets but doesn't realistically let you do that in a helpful way. Most players invest in a physical shield that uses mana as a defense and doesn't allow you to use your block; this to me is a screaming flaw. So to get through a wave of baddies without being seriously hurt, you need to use an overpowered spell and consume 10 mana potions? That sounds like a cheap exploit, not like enjoyable combat. In many ways, this game rewards you for overpowering easy spells and punishes you for trying to take part in actual melee or ranged combat.The enemies seem to be very inconsistent. You will face an enemy and find it easy to mow down, then moments later you'll come across another one and it seems to have infinite health. I don't know what the basis is, exactly. When you run into some bandits on the way to a destination and it takes 5 minutes to get rid of them in the same repetitive chop chop chop get knocked over drink mana put up shield chop chop chop sequence, it just becomes tedius. You can recruit some expensive mercenaries to help you, but in my experience the auto target likes to aim at them during battle. So I'll have ten generic looking bandits, each with a totally random mystery amount of health, swarming me while my auto-target aims at my mercenary or the person I'm supposed to be escorting to safety. What? How does that help me in any way?There are two cosmetic mechanics in the game that are really cool to a point but become rather irritating. First of all, your character ages each time you level up skills. This is an interesting mechanic, except that nothing else ages in the same way and it is way too drastic. By time you finish leveling, you look old and withered (you are 65). Meanwhile, everone else looks EXACTLY THE SAME. The children in the game are still children. This makes aging utterly meaningless; it just ruins your toon if you care about how he looks. The other mechanic is scarring: As you get damaged in battle, you develop scars over time. This is actually really cool, until you realize that your face gets cut up like butter. Given the awful combat system I mentioned, you are GOING to get attacked and after only a few hits you will get a new cut or your old cuts will become more prominent. In the end, it's just scratching up your character for no reason. The only thing that can stop it is the afforementioned mana shield which basically strips combat of any actual skill and devolves it into hacking at your opponent as fast as you can so as to avoid being hit, and gulping down mana potions if you do get hit.The characters in this game are f***ing irritating. There were a few funny moments that genuinely made me laugh, but for each of those there are dozens of nerve grating lines of dialogue. For a game that's so cartoonish and silly, there isn't really any heart to it because the storyline is entirely cliché and there isn't a single likeable or relateable character in the game There are a lot of small features in the game like the chance to buy and sell for profit, marriage, owning a house, etc. Unfortunately, all of them are mere distractions and offer no real depth whatsoever. Since none of the characters are actually likeable, and marrying one just involves pressing "laugh" "flirt" "show off muscles" and giving gifts, it is entirely purposeless. You buy a house so that they can live in it, or so you can rent it out for gold. Let's talk about gold: There is a memory game you can play in the tavern that is extremely easy to win and on which you can bet thousands of gold pieces. You can win all the money you need from it, making everything to do with currency in the game entirely meaningless. Why should I do quests boasts (an interestnig feature where you bet money on accomplishing quests with special limitations) if I can just make all that money from a game of memory? Why wouldn't I just buy all the best armor there is if I can get all the money I need at any time? Any progression pertaining to the spending of money is undermined. I think the best example of how this game tacks in random features to make it seem better than it is is the experience orbs: When you defeat an enemy, it leaves experience orbs which you collect for experience. Well, why the hell are they little orbs which I can miss? Why wouldn't the game just allow me to have the experience? That exemplifies how the game sort of makes "features" out of non features. Why would I choose to be evil when it'll literally be like "save this person or brutally murder them?" Why would I buy and sell for money when I can gamble for it easily? Why would I choose to be a swordsman or archer when I can just acquire some overpowered spells?The sad thing is, for all the roleplaying features the game boasts, there is actually no real variety in how you play. Things are pretty much predetermined for you, and the choices are an illusion or a gimmick.I dare anyone who thinks I'm not being fair to this game to look up a strategy forum. Pretty much any serious player used loopholes, exploits, or overpowered spells in order to play the game and do well. If you want to actually play the game in the way it presents itself and that has meaning to it, you will probably find it isn't worth the trouble.Altogether, I'm glad I finally got around to playing a game from the Fable series just so I could check it out, but I don't plan to actually finish the game as there is no reason to do so.

number of helpful: 9 of 29 people (31%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2016
												I think this game may have been great in 2004, but I never played it back then. Nowadays I don't like it mostly because of it's combat system. You have to score as many consecutive hits as possible without getting hit yourself, to get the combat multiplier up. Unfortunately when I see anyone attack it's far too late to get a block up/dodge. You can kill things this way, but it feels like button smashing to me. The flying nymphs who constantly summon melee fighters to attack you are incredibly annoying, as you can only hit them with your bow with the target lock on system, which i could not get to lock on to the enemy i wanted to attack but instead the nearest enemy, which was not the nymph but all the summoned melees.The good/evil choice system is interesting, i just couldn't find a motivation to do anything evil. I thought the hero suffered enough evil in his youth and got rescued by good ones to feel that good is the only path for him and there are no great rewards for being evil. BUT it's still better than Fable III which i could only stand for 2 hours before deleting it.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2015
												I bought it because it supposedly had an amazing story. Other than a few good parts (escaping from prison was cool), it was mostly memorable only for the annoyances. The "Chicken Chaser" joke was funny for the first three hours, but the repetition of the same voice acting wherever I went slowly drove me insane. The fact that ALL guards EVERYWHERE look and sound EXACTLY the same also killed any immersion and sense of exploration. It's like the kingdom got its guards from Kamino.I ended up skipping most of the sidequests and unlockables, and I look back on the game as somewhat of a waste.It probably held up better at the time, but it's no Bioshock. It's not even Skyrim's little brother in terms of story (and Skyrim only had a decent main storyline). Gameplay is surprisingly good for a game this old though (lightning!) and it has a blend of action and tab-targeting combat, so there's that.  I still can't recommend it though. Go play something else if you want gameplay, and avoid this one if you want a good story.

number of helpful: 6 of 26 people (23%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 8, 2014
												I wish there was a "I liked it but I don't think it's worth getting" option. I've played through this game three times, two to completion; and the third time is why I don't recommend getting this game. My first time I played a warrior, the game was a piece of cake. I had like two points in mage and so when I got to the point where you had to used ranged -- it was slow and I went through a ton of healing potions but doable. The same thing with playing a mage. If anything after a few levels it was beyond easy to run around and basically wipe the floor with anything that came close. There's lots of threads that talk about how OP mage is for good reason, the game is a cake walk with it.But the third playthough I wanted to do a pure archer. Only turns out you can't. There are certain quests where you will get mobbed even trying to be extremely sneaky and one shot people with max range -- certain quests essentially require close combat. I don't mind when a certain combat style or class, is overpowered and much easier to play through. In fact that's sometimes a plus; but to have a whole class be nearly impossible to win with does bother me. I don't actually think you can complete the final boss battle as an archer -- it's again structured to give an advantage to mages and warriors who can take damage close combat style. Maybe I'm missing something, because there's certainly gear and setups for all three combat styles, but it just feels like range is really underpowered throughout. Overall, you really do become insanely powerful proportionally quickly. The later levels were honestly overly easy, even with the additional content added, I still breezed through it all. Wearing plate as a warrior you're essentially invulnerable; and you can get several swords that can single shot almost everything. There's no real challenge to the game.That all being said -- I consider it "adventure game lite" in that it's short enough to beat in an afternoon and have seen all the content and feel satisfied that you played a whole game. Excluding silver key and demon door hunting there's about 7 hours of content per playthrough, which makes in a nice fix for wanting to play a RPG but not wanting to invest 100+ hours in an elder scrolls game.I would say it was kiddie -- but there's enough sexual innuendoes, and a brothel outright at one point, that make it rated-M and so it just falls into a category where it feels like something I would let a kid play as introduction to the genre but it has moments of being a little to edgy for that.Pros+ Easy difficulty+ Good lengthCons- Unmemorable story- poorly balanced combat triangle

number of helpful: 29 of 78 people (37%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												The game was one of my faves when it was released. Unlike most RPGs, there were immense amounts of choices on how to build, and essentially, how to play as well. There is a main storyline, of course, and a presecribed path to take, but the game does sell on its promised choose your destiny format.That said, gameplay is quite broken in general, and takes adjustment if you wish to scrape by without the broken aspects. For instance, you can make money simply buy buying and selling stuff to the same shopowner, as his stocks of items fluctuate the cost. Additionally, the most broken skill in the game is Physical Shield, as it not only keeps you from taking any damage at all, but you don't get thrown around, and you never lose your precious combat multiplier, so long as you chug mana potions, and that helps break the game wide open for you. But, in general, any character can grind to the point of being all-powerful, with some time invested, of course, as any build path is open for any character, as even though "Being good" or "Being bad" does influence your skill pool minimally, it's even more minute because fluctuating between good and bad is not difficult (especially for being bad...). All that aside, the game was pretty much the first game to give a hero any type of plotline choices that I saw, and I must commend them for that. However, the game has a poor look for being released on Steam nowadays, and only diehard plot enthusiasts or general gamers who want to experience it all will enjoy this. I had to buy it for old time's sake, and while it has managed to accrue a bit of playtime, I don't see many out there enjoying this for what it's worth in this age of gaming. I really don't know of anything like Fable still, and I enjoyed it more than Fable III (haven't played the others...), but getting through the early game will be hard to weather through to get to the better parts of the plotline and become strong enough to feel less than some shrimpy character at times. In my opinion, casters are very underpowered, partly because Physical Shield is so overpowered, and will sap your mana if you don't kill things fast enough as a caster. The other paths get so much more powerful, and I don't see why you'd even bother. Still a huge step in the right direction for a choose-your-own-path type adventure, but there is still a clearly prescribed path, like any adventure with an adversary. It just has good areas you can stray from the path a bit, and they will effect your destiny in various ways.I checked... I played it on Steam for 2nd most hours compared to any reviewer, and that's not all that much... I don't know what that could mean for certain, but I'd guess that the majority of reviewers who upvoted it are in it for the nostalgia. It was a good game in its heyday, but I believe that the strengths of this game would be overshadowed too much by its weaknesses in today's gaming environment, even at its lower price. There are a number of games that deserve being carried over into today, but while this one is on the fence for me, I'm leaving my opinion where it was; This game doesn't hold enough appeal to stand out amongst today's games.

number of helpful: 7 of 29 people (24%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												Peter Molyneux can suck a big ol' butt, with his damn overhyping of every game he has created. "Oh, trees and other plants will grow as you progress in a realistic manner! Your choices matter! raiding a village can have a big effect on the world, a forest can probably grow in its place or it will become the new base for bandits! Your choices matter! The people of Albion's look on you will change depending on your morals! YOUR CHOICES, ♥♥♥♥ING, MATTER. What we got in truth was a mediocre, ridiculously easy, and downright boring excuse for an RPG, where your choices have absolutely no effect on ANYTHING. So, on to the review, my time with Fable started off with excitement, I enjoyed the game in the beginning until I noticed the flaws. The first and one of my biggest problems, healing items were absurdley common, I found them at literally every turn I made, not to mention: Resurrection phials, something that keeps you from actually dying and lose your progress, were also needlessyly common, not that I ever needed them, I had over 99 health potion on me at all times, not to mention I had well over 500 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ things of red meat, which resulted in me ALWAYS having max resurrection phials.Next awful part, the story, Now what makes an RPG good besides the feeling of growing stronger and feeling like a hero? A non-generic, non-cliché, interesting and well thought out story. Does Fable the lost chapters include this, not in the least bit, it has a boring story with an overused theme that has been in every fable game to this date, "Oh I'm a Hero looking to seek revenge on the stupid butts that killed a certain member of my family, erp a derp a dur!" Characters are uninteresting and have no soul (well more soul than Fable 2 I guess, what a ♥♥♥♥ing mess).On to combat, role a mage/melee build, use berserk and physical and divine fury or infernal wrath, repeatedly click using whatever overpowered as hell weapon you own, assign both mana and health potion to 1 and 2 on your keyboard and spam the ♥♥♥♥ out of those, win the game.Finally, what makes Fable completely fall apart, the overhyped theme of your choices effecting the world. Peter Molyneux originally would constantly brag about how every morale choice you make in Fable ompletely effect those around you, when I played through the whole game, at no point did I think that my choices were effecting ANYTHING, I actually played through sections twice to see the difference between my choices, did anything change? Barely, except for my devil horns (oh no I'm slightly more ugly than I was before.)Overally Fable the lost chapters is really not a too good of a game, it can hold your attention for roughly 30 hours or so but has no real replayability, luckily it is only $10 on steam, so it isn't really stealing your money.

												Fable - TLC was a good game long ago. Some might still enjoy it today. number of helpful: 26 of 73 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												This game shows it's age. Not just in graphics, but in plotline. Maybe the voice acting and side quest mechanics were interesting at the time, but now? Meh. Specific points:Marketed as a game where you could have influence in the world, but....-You can be mayor. What does it mean to be mayor? Nothing. You don't do anything, noone reacts.-You can own property. What does it mean to own property? Not much. You can upgrade the furnishings, hang trophies on the wall, and collect rent. And then never go back, because why would you?-You can get married. Find one of the many nameless NPCs and stand in front of them to show off your manly pectorals. Then throw a ring at them. You now have access to the sex scene, which is a fade to black with suggestive voice acting. Never interact with your wife again.-You can be good or evil. What's the difference? Halos or demon horns. You could slaughter the innocent one day, vanquish the wicked the next, and that's totally fine.The running theme is that none of these decisions impact the story greatly. You can occasionally choose: "kill this dude" or "don't kill this dude." That'll affect 2 or 3 scenes. Basically doesn't matter.Not sure what to say about the core gameplay. I found it very easy, but YMMV.======================================================Response to first comment:I am skeptical of your rebuttal, and examined faqs and forum posts to investigate.Are you sure about that mayor thing? Everything indicates that it does nothing. I did learn that I COULD purchase and rent out buildings and businesses other than the marital homes in each town, but you have to kill the tenant to do so. Which...geez. Talk about a hostile takeover. *rimshot* Anyway, nobody reacted to me as mayor. And no new properties became available for rent. All signs point to violent death being the only way other property becomes available.Still not sure what the point of renting things out is. It'd take an awful lot of time just making the rounds accumulating rent to earn the money back, and what is there to spend the money on? There's some legendary sword you can buy with it I guess, but there's dozens of legendary weapons sitting around everywhere anyways. You can pour it into the temple of Avo to shift alignment over to good. That's something I guess, but getting good alignment just happened as a natural result of going through the main quest, since every monster or bandit killed gave some good alignment points.Didn't realize the spouse would give gifts. So that's something.All indications also point to never having a child of one's own, that was added in Fable 2.  If you marry the right person in Bowerstone, and they happen to be a single parent of one of the children in the school, then the child may be brought along. No sign that the child would eventually act like you. The aging mechanic gets weird here too, since you might get married at age 30, get married, meet your stepchild, then advance levels to age 65 and the stepchild is still the same age. Good and evil have more result than most of these other effects, but...eh. Complaining that I'm not locked in? Hm. Perhaps I would like to be locked in a little bit. Redemption and corruption stories are interesting, and I don't want to always have to be the stupendously good-aligned butterfly-attracting goodly hero of goodness just because I ate some Tofu one time, but yeah. When I decided to try the other alignment, it was unsatisfying. Swapping the extremes is just too easy, and too without consequence. It doesn't seem the game particularly cares. Townsfolk alternately run away from me or come around to applaud me, and both are kind of annoying. Big clusters of sound files all being played at once either way.I don't know what your last comment is supposed to imply. Do you mean I shouldn't have needed to spend that much time to complete the main storyline? I could have dropped the sidequests and paid even less attention to the economy, I guess. Do you mean I should have realized that I could kill townspeople and buy their houses? I was definitely surprised to learn that, but I don't see why I would.

number of helpful: 10 of 39 people (26%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Not bad but not great, though it is only 10 bucks so you're getting what you pay for. This game feels pretty restrictive by today's standards in terms of what you can do and where you can roam. Also the good/evil mechanic is very simplistic compared to other games, even ones that are older than Fable (being evil just means helping out bandits, other games allow you to join assassin's guilds or criminal syndicates, or even to join a despotic tryannical government over a democratic people's revolt). The characters lack complexity or depth, your main "rival" Willow for instance seems to despise you for no other reason than to give you an opportunity to have a rival. I did enjoy the ability to be an entrepreneur and invest in properties, trade goods for profit etc. and the character customisation, I guess I just expected a lot more though considering the hype around this game. 5/10 from me.

												Bought this after reading so much praise on Metacritics and the likes of it...Well, i have to say i thoroughly disagree with the critics and user reviews...This game is just a botched attempt at creating an interesting RPG experience:the whole idea of following your character through his life... just not true, you play just chunks of the prologue where you are a youngling and then you are an adult like everybody else in the proper game.-- Combat F****G sucks! Never experienced such flawed combat system, you just mindlessly punch your mouse buttons and hope to not be interrupted... pure boredom after a while-- Incredibly silly storyline with childish writings ( sister appearance is just nonsensical )-- Can't speak for everybody else but with my SB X-Fi audio card the dialogue were just massively flawed, like they were coming only from my left or right side altogheter.. no actual mixing left me appalled and annoyed after a whileThere are MUCH MUCH better games in this RPG sub genre, don't waste your time on this one

												I saw Peter Molyneux at a grocery store in Los Angeles yesterday. I told him how cool it was to meet him in person, but I didn’t want to be a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and bother him and ask him for photos or anything.He said, “Oh, like you’re doing now?”I was taken aback, and all I could say was “Huh?” but he kept cutting me off and going “huh? huh? huh?” and closing his hand shut in front of my face. I walked away and continued with my shopping, and I heard him chuckle as I walked off. When I came to pay for my stuff up front I saw him trying to walk out the doors with like fifteen Milky Ways in his hands without paying.The girl at the counter was very nice about it and professional, and was like “Sir, you need to pay for those first.” At first he kept pretending to be tired and not hear her, but eventually turned back around and brought them to the counter.When she took one of the bars and started scanning it multiple times, he stopped her and told her to scan them each individually “to prevent any electrical infetterence,” and then turned around and winked at me. I don’t even think that’s a word. After she scanned each bar and put them in a bag and started to say the price, he kept interrupting her by yawning really loudly.

Posted: November 29, 2013
												When the original Fable title launched on the original Xbox console, I bought it and loved it so much that I recommended it to my friends. When the Lost Chapters version launched a year or more later, I traded in my Fable game and upgraded to The Lost Chapters. In 2009, I purchased the PC version at retail for only $10 to have it on my PC. I then purchased it again recently off of Steam (at a price only a madman would refuse to pay) to have a Steam copy always available. I also plan on buying the HD remake coming to Xbox 360 in 2014. I have purchased the game 4 times, and will purchase it for a 5th time. This game is fantastic, and is the best in the series. Buy this and give it a play through if you have not done so. It's funny and charming.

Posted: May 27, 2014
												This was a very good game with a lot of character control (in-game appearance, personality, interactions, and various, evolve-able fighting styles). I played this game in Spanish to help me learn, so for my purposes it had just a little less repetitiveness than I wanted but that also forced me to learn more and made the game a fast pace. I beat the game both as pure good and pure evil and experimented with some of the exploits. Fable claims that different choices you make in game affect the rest of the game and it is definitely true. I especially like how the game can differentiate between minor things that you do. For example, killing an innocent npc as a pure good character will still make the other npcs in the area scream and run away from you. Likewise, doing some random good thing as pure evil with people around will cause them to stop running for a bit and clap as if you're not about to kill them all. 3:) There are also levels of attractiveness and scariness that influence what others think of you. I think it's great that the game forces you to fatten up if you want a side-quest type item. All in all, great game; definitely worth playing.

Posted: June 1, 2014
												I used to play this game on Xbox when it was just Fable. The extra storyline in this version just blows away any other RPG i have played in quite a while. The only new-ish RPG that comes close to this game that has the same style of play would be Fable 2, yes i know its the same people but thats the thing noone else makes a game quite as good as this IMO. So lets go over the 4 categories I like to write my reviews on (other than Combat Arms, doesnt even deserve the time anymore, yes it used to deserve it). Now onwards,1) Graphics 8/10Obviously the graphics are going to look and seem old, but thats one fo the tings i love about this game. It gives the game a classic feeling. If you prefer older textures that dont look all 8-bit then this game has just the right graphics for you. (I would do 10/10 but I do have to take in to account some glitchy textures like your hair looking wiry, etc.)2) Storyline 12/10 (HOLY SH#T)This games storyline will suck you in and make you feel as if you were living it. The narration is just amazing giving you in depth background and current information on whats happening. In the very beginning you start off as a boy trying to get a present for your sisters birthday so you go around doing good deeds so your father will pay you for them (1 gold piece per good deed). *SPOILER ALERT* If you havent played skip to the next rating, After your sister gets her present she knows something is not quite right. You hide in a field while the entire village you knew and loved is being burned and its people slaughtered. A guild master comes and rescues you and you start training as a hero from there on out the story gets more complex and interesting. By far, one of the best storylines I have EVER had the PRIVILEGE to play.3) Character development 7.5/10Yeah this game is slightly lacking in chracter development. You get more famous, you get good or evil, and you choose all your skills. This might sound incredibly amazing but the way they chose to lay it all out is slightly boring. You doo good or bad deeds your alignment changes (obviously). As your alignment changes you get horns and red mist if your evil and butterfllys and a halo if your good. You skills are Strength, Skill, and Will. Stregth is your health, damage and damge taken. Skill is speed, guile(sneakyness), and damage you do with cross/bows. Will is actually the main thing I loved as far as the character development go's hence the 7.5, You are able to choose skills that heal you, damage your foes, make you do more damage, make you take less damage, among an array of other spells you can buy all of them (eventually) for your experience. You earn experience based on which attack you use to deal with enemies and general experience that can be used for all three (skill,strength, and will) trees at your disposal. The alignment and renown is a little clunky but the Skills are very in-depth (if you dont like spending alot of time figuring out what works for you and what you like just stop playing RPGs their not for you)4) Gameplay 9.5/10This games gameplay is amazing as well. I cant give it a 10/10 however because of one tiny detail that I cant get over. When your stealing stuff and noone is looking at you but since they are in the same area you still get caught. THat is so unrealistic. If they didnt see you do it HOW ARE YOU IN TROUBLE. >:(I Anyways other than that the games mechanics and fighting are all very well thought out and its runs great on pretty much all computers (because its an older game).The fighting is in depth yet still easy to control and the other controls for just moving and using spells etc, are well thought out because you dont ahve to use complicated keyboard controls to kick a$$. Its that simple great mechanics make for a great game.OVER ALL RATING Should you play it: If you dont you should blow up your computer.Do I recommend this: YES but only to those people who are serious about RPG's because its a little in deptha and challenging if your not a RPG lover.Rating out of 100: 92.5/100 ( As far as im concerned no game will ever earn 100/100 from me (EVER)

Posted: July 2, 2014
												One of my favorite roleplaying games of all time. Originally owned it on the Xbox before the additional 'Lost Chapters' version came out. I saw this version on sale during the Steam Summer Sale and thought to myself, I can't go wrong repurchasing a game, with further expanded story content for a mere $3.39 at the time. Easily was worth every penny, as I got over 29hrs out of it on my replay, thus far.          I must say, even years later as an adult, grown up from my childhood, I can still revel in the excellent gameplay/story. This game was supposed to be monumental and break the mold for choices in a game, easily succeeding in the task, inspiring future games in the genre to come. Thusly, if you are a fan of RPGs and open world combat, feel free to pick this gem up. If anything, I can thoroughly endorse this game, with a lifelong gamer's seal of approval. Have fun in Albion if you found this review helpful.                                                                                                                                                                          10/10 - James

Posted: December 31, 2013
												I loved this game when I had it on Xbox. I have heard and seen it as being one of the most disapointing games of it's time, but I loved it. I went into the game blind, and loved it. I think it was because it was expected to be much more, but I was very happy where it was. It had plenty of action, a good story, great characters, and a lot of humor. It had a quite ElderScrolls feel to the leveling up. Instead of like most RPGs, where you get EXP from killing enemies and used that to level up, Fable is a bit different. You do get EXP from killing, but you also get it from doing the killing. You shoot something with an arrow, you get skill EXP. Blast them with lightning, you get will EXP. Bash them with a hammer, you get strength EXP. They do not mix together, so you can't play as pure mage and have a high health. Not from Will EXP, at least. This is where the General EXP come in, the stuff you get from killing and quests. That can be put towards anything. Also, what you do in the game effects your appearence. Like to crunch on little newborn chickens (yes, you can do that) and kill people? A red mist will rise from your feet and eyes, you will become pale, flies will be drawn to you like the corpses you leave behind, and you grow horns (also destroying the majority of your hairstyle). People will run in terror from you, and hate you though your power will keep them from doing anything. But if you play as good, people will flock to, you will get a halo and a beam of light when you stand still. I think your eyes change color, though it has been a long time. Max out strength and you will look like a bodybuilder. Will will make you glow. I can't remember what Skill does. Fighting badly leaves you with scars.I could keep going on, but you should play it yourself. My only complaints are that the GuildMaster gets annoying "Your health is low. Have you any potions, or food", and I am having trouble getting the game to run on my computer even though it should be able to run it no problem. But once I get it up and running I won't be doing much else.

Posted: May 5, 2014
Review:The very first Fable game in my opinion is better than the 3rd and the Fable: The Journey, but cannot isn't as good as the 2nd. Many can argue that point due to P.M.'s false promises, but I felt I enjoyed the 2nd one far more. This review is about Fable - The Lost Chapters NOT the other games, so let's talk about this title, shall we? Fable - The Lost Chapters, the extended edition of... Fable, is a game that many people thought could rival against The Legend of Zelda. Many people have mentioned that this is essentially Zelda, but a more mature version of it, with a different take on RPG Adventure titles by Microsoft. The game has a pretty mediocre story, but that wasn't really what Fable - The Lost Chapters is about in my opinion. Sure, story is very important in Role Playing titles, but this isn't a game where I actually cared about my character or any other character to be honest. I just did what I felt like doing, and that's exactly why I liked this title so much! There's FREEDOM involved! Sure, it's no where near The Elder Scrolls type of freedom, but for it's time it was wonderful, and arguably it still is! The decisions you made had people love you or fear you, and that is why I enjoyed this game, because your character ages, and you feel your decisions effected the growth of your character in the way you wanted him to be at!Personal Experience:I played Fable; both vanilla version of the game and The Lost Chapters on the orignal Xbox, and I've gotta say this is still one of my favorite franchises that Microsoft owns the rights towards. It's a darn shame that Fable 2 never saw the light of day on the PC, because I'd probably still be playing that game if I still owned a Xbox 360; despite finishing all the quests and racking up all that dough by collecting rent from all the houses and stores I owned. I had a snobby Good Guy and a generous Evil Dude, and it was just funny to hear the NPCs fear me, but are thankful I was generous, and vice versa. The jokes in the Fable Universe are relatable to Monty Python's, and that's awesome! Fable - The Lost Chapters had lots of things that were enjoyable about it, but when Fable 2 came out I just couldn't stop playing with the dog. The only thing I actually cared about in the game was a dog that helped me find items by shoveling the areas he was also digging up. I wish I could go into more detail about my experience with Fable - The Lost Chapter, but I just didn't care for it as much compared to Fable 2. In Fable 3 I liked the combat a lot more than the others, but I didn't like how they didn't make it seem like a RPG. There was something about the 3rd title that didn't sit with me, but it wasn't a bad game, it just took away an element that I enjoyed about Fable 2.~ twitch.tv/samsterboy ~
