												A lot of my peers have written reviews, so I am going to express my opinion on the Steam version of Fable TLC. I remember being 11 years old and getting this game for Christmas for Xbox (yes, the original one) and thinking this cover looks cool, lets hope the story line holds up. My parents knew I was into the Sims and all that, so a decision game might be of my interest. Boy, were they right. This game allows for so many possibilities, and with TLC allows for the good guys to get a sword for being heroic (I had the first one, and I remember when I first beat the game and saved my sister, they were like "Oh, you were so herioc, giving up power like that" and not getting a major reward for it. Thankfully, this game has a reward, so no complaints there).If you are looking for a game to stear you down a storyline with little to no variance, this game will be disappointing. This game allows you to make choices and live with the consequences, being a hero, villian, or unprecedented acts of both. Out of all the Fables, this one is definitely worth replaying over and over again. When I found this game on Steam, I had to have it, just to relive some nostalgia of being a kid again. Thanks for reading. GreenEggsPwn

Posted: March 31, 2014
												This game is truly amazing, I freakin' love it! In my opinion, this is the only truly impressive game in the Fable series. In this game you play as The Hero Of Oakvale, a young child with dreams of greatness. The game sees you grow from a young punk, into a daring hero, dark warrior, or powerful mage. You can be anything you want in the game, you can even be a naked guy who runs around murdering people with a pic-axe! The game has fairly good graphics for the time, and I think they've aged fairly well.This game's soundtrack is one of the best soundtracks I've heard in an RPG! The theme tune was done by the amazing Danny Elfman, the same guy who did the music for the Spiderman trilogy and The Simpsons. The game allows true character evolution, as your character will evolve depending upon what skills you choose to focus on and your chosen allignment. For example, if you focus on building your strength skills you will become a big muscly giant. If you focus on being a good guy, you will look like Super Saiyan Goku. The game allows you to be whatever you want, and that's what I enjoy.The game does have problems though, and I'm going to avoid talking about the false advertising, because everyone has already bashed on it. One of the main annoyances I've had with the game is it's difficulty. It's way too easy, seriously! Five hours into the game and I'm able to bat everything away with zero effort! Almost all of the magic spells are overpowered and break the game. Do yourself a favor and avoid getting the Slow Time spell, it will kill any fun you can have. On top of that, there are various exploits in the game to get more powerful in a short amount of time. One such example is that the game features Ages potions, which give you a fair boost in EXP in a certain skill tree.The problem? If you have your combat multiplier up high enough and drink the potion, you'll get mad EXP for almost nothing! I had my combat multiplier at 14 and drank a potion, and got 14800 EXP in the will category! Also, the story was fairly predictable at times, and some of the characters seemed flat. I never really liked Briar Rose all that much, and Maze was just lame to me. I'd like Guildmaster more if he didn't pipe random advice into my ear every five seconds. And I found that some sidequests were either really lame, or didn't off much reward. One such quest is one where I have to acquire for blue mushrooms to cure a sick child, but the reward wasn't really that great in the grand scheme of things.Despite all that, I highly reccomend this game! If you're new to open-world RPGs and are on the fence of getting into these kinds of games, Fable would be a good starter for you. It isn't as large or as immerssive as Oblivon, Fallout 3, or Kingdoms Of Amalur, but you'll still get some bang out of your buck. Fable introduced me to the world of action RPGs, and I will never regret buying this game used back in the day. When this game goes on sale, I highly suggest picking it up. One final thing to note: This game does not have a difficulty slider, so you're stuck with the preset difficulty. Like said, it's easy but totally worth the price tag.

Posted: March 6, 2016
												Fable is a game I've played several times, and at first I thought it was fantastic. I loved the story, the world, and it was really one of the first RPG's I really got into. I owned it on Xbox, and after losing it I thought I'd buy it again on steam. And after playing and beating Fable for the hundredth time, I've only just now began to realize this game is far from perfect.Don't get me wrong, Fable is still a good game, and decent RPG overall. The graphics hold up pretty well today, which is impressive for a game that's going on 12 years old. But that's really where Fable ends, "Good" and "Decent" The story has really weird pacing, the game's length is far from impressive, and the games lack of side quests really detract from replay value. Another thing I've come to dislike about fable is how simple it is. The game has very few deep and interesting mechanics, and some of the ones that are there are broken (ex. the morality and ageing systems)It may seem like I'm harping on it, but I would still recommend Fable to both casual gamers, and fans of action RPGs. While it may seem lack luster, Fable is still a solid experience with great combat, good characters, an interesting world to explore, and plenty of chickens to kick. It was a fantastic third person action RPG experience back in 2004, and while it has aged over the years, I think Falble is a purchase that you won't regret.

Posted: December 31, 2013
												I loved this game when I had it on Xbox. I have heard and seen it as being one of the most disapointing games of it's time, but I loved it. I went into the game blind, and loved it. I think it was because it was expected to be much more, but I was very happy where it was. It had plenty of action, a good story, great characters, and a lot of humor. It had a quite ElderScrolls feel to the leveling up. Instead of like most RPGs, where you get EXP from killing enemies and used that to level up, Fable is a bit different. You do get EXP from killing, but you also get it from doing the killing. You shoot something with an arrow, you get skill EXP. Blast them with lightning, you get will EXP. Bash them with a hammer, you get strength EXP. They do not mix together, so you can't play as pure mage and have a high health. Not from Will EXP, at least. This is where the General EXP come in, the stuff you get from killing and quests. That can be put towards anything. Also, what you do in the game effects your appearence. Like to crunch on little newborn chickens (yes, you can do that) and kill people? A red mist will rise from your feet and eyes, you will become pale, flies will be drawn to you like the corpses you leave behind, and you grow horns (also destroying the majority of your hairstyle). People will run in terror from you, and hate you though your power will keep them from doing anything. But if you play as good, people will flock to, you will get a halo and a beam of light when you stand still. I think your eyes change color, though it has been a long time. Max out strength and you will look like a bodybuilder. Will will make you glow. I can't remember what Skill does. Fighting badly leaves you with scars.I could keep going on, but you should play it yourself. My only complaints are that the GuildMaster gets annoying "Your health is low. Have you any potions, or food", and I am having trouble getting the game to run on my computer even though it should be able to run it no problem. But once I get it up and running I won't be doing much else.

Posted: January 4, 2016
												Quick Review:This is the basic game I remember playing on the original XBox. Both fun and frustrating at times.Pros- Installs and launches flawlessly under Windows 7 Professional (my first concern, didn't see it addressed anywhere else)- Supports high resolution, AA, and high textures/details (just be sure to disable VSync)- No hesitations, hiccups, etc (unlike Fable Anniversary)- Has the original, cartoonish graphics that just go better with the atmosphere of the gameCons- Only (natively) supports the use of keyboard and mouse  ** You CAN get around this by using 3rd party keyboard to controller mapping (xpadder, CTK, JoyToKey, etc)- Saving is a bit screwy (I may be mis-remembering this though), see bottom of review for details- Does not have Steam Accomplishments/BadgesBottom line, pay the $10 for this version and you don't have the "better" graphics that actually make the game look worse. You won't have the slow-downs, stuttering, etc, You'll need to look into a keyboard to joystick program if you are dead set on using a gamepad, but the game is easily played with keyboard and mouse.A Note On Saving: This game has set savepoints that you must reach or your progress is lost. Examples:- Starting the Game: Finish a few quests to get Gold to purchase a gift... but if you complete only two of these quests and quit, you have to start over. You have to complete the town to get an "Autosave"- Guild Training: Go through the basics and a few tests, but don't complete the final step of getting your badge? Too bad, even if you saved mid-level, you now have to start the training over from the very beginning.Basically, you need to fully complete quests to the point that you see the words "AUTOSAVING" (or something like that) appear on screen.BUY THIS VERSION AND NOT THE ANNIVERSARY EDITION!!! This one will never be on sale, but at $10... it's a steal!

Posted: January 28, 2014
												Fable is a franchise I've had a bit of a rocky relationship with. My first experience was Fable II (having completely missed the original), and it is one of my favorite games of the Xbox 360 era. Fable III, not so much. With Fable Anniversary coming out soon, the remake of the now 10 year old RPG, I figured why not just get a cheap copy of the original and see what it’s all about. The premise starts you as a young boy in the town of Oakvale in the land of Albion, who has a loving sister and parents. But that kind of story makes for a boring video game, so a group of bandits attack your village, kidnaping your mother and sister, and murdering practically everyone else, including your father. But before you meet your own demise, you’re saved by a hero named Maze, and are inducted into the Guild of Heroes. In the world of Albion, a hero isn't just a title but an occupation, something you learn by joining the guild. The game switches over to your teenage years for your guild training and then finally to adulthood after you become a true hero. This is the first neat trick Fable does, giving your character, and the world, a real sense of growth. Seeing the world change around you as you grow and make choices is neat, and gives everything a sense of place.Fable has the typical “your character glows if they’re good and pale skin and devil horns if you’re evil” that most games with morality like to do, but how you spec your character also affects them. If you put a bunch of points into strength, your character will become more bulky and muscular as a result, while if you put a lot of points into magic, you get glowing blue tattoos on your face. Unfortunately the options felt a bit too simple preventing me from having my character look exactly how I want. I like my characters to be a bit on the thin and scrawny side, probably because I myself am thin and scrawny, but there wasn't any way to go full on melee combat without forcing yourself to become a hulking beast. A little more variety on this front would have been cool.In combat your main tool will be your melee, of which you are given a nice selection of fast swords like the katana, something with a bit more punch like great swords, and even more massive weapons like hammers. There’s not much in the ways of multiple attacks, it’s rather simplistic with one button for attacking and another for using a flourish attack when you build one up. It’s all about timing and avoiding your enemies with blocks and dodges. Getting in hits and avoiding them yourself builds up your combat multiplier, letting you deal more damage. It’s a system that works but by the end of the game I found myself a little tired of it. The ranged combat, bows and crossbows, I found to be rather useless. It has its place in certain situations but you’re not going to want to spec your character into a full ranged one, which is a disappointment. Magic is by far the most interesting and varied. There’s a ton of spells all put into a bunch of categories. So if you want to go full on attack magic you can throw points into lighting, fire, etc. Even if you’re melee focused like I was, it’s worth getting spells like slow time, which I found invaluable during the later parts of the game.The core of Fable has you taking on guild quests, making choices, and being the "hero." The moral choice system is bit too black and white for my tastes. You’re never really given any grey area and it’s always very clear which is good and which is evil. Having a character say something like, "you can go do this quest for this reward, or I guess if you were some sort of evil person you could always just kill me," doesn't really leave much to the imagination. One nice thing however is the game does provide full good and full evil side quests, usually having them be on opposite sides of the same problem. Will you take the quest the farmers put up to help stop the bandit raids, or will you take the quest the bandits put up to help with the raid. Stuff like that’s more fun because it lets you put your intentions forward right away rather than giving you some black and white choice half way through the quest.Another big component of the game is the interaction system with NPCs. You hero has a ton of different emotions they can express ranging from simple ones like laughing or saying hi, too more morality specific ones like flexing your heroic muscles or giving an evil laugh, too the ridiculously absurd such as farting and doing the chicken dance. Sadly I never found myself having any real gameplay reason to use them past their first time. For example you can flirt with NPCs and eventually have them fall in love with you. Cool idea, but no real benefit doing it. I didn't even have to try honestly. By the end of the game, every girl, and even some men, had a big enough heart above them that I could simply walk up to them, hand them a wedding ring, and be married before the sun set without even trying. The ability to interact with NPCs is a neat idea, and admittedly I got excited when they started to call me by my title I picked out and talking about past quests I did, but overall it feels more like a proof of concept than a fully implemented feature.The story does go to some interesting places and has a large focus on family, with the hero's sister and mother coming heavily into play. This does give everything a more personal feel to it and I found myself caring in the hero's journey and his seeking revenge. The antagonist, Jack of Blades, lives up to his awesome name by being a great creepy villain. My only wish was that is motivations were explained better as I was never quite sure why he was doing what he was doing other than to just be evil.It’s worth noting that I played the PC version, known as Fable: The Lost Chapters, which contains a bunch of extra characters, side quests, and continues the story after the final boss battle, which by the way was pretty weak. The extra content is cool, adding new characters and extra story that is welcome, but doesn't feel completely necessary. Also the new final boss somehow manages to be easier and lamer than the original.Graphically the game holds up pretty well for being 10 years old. Stuff like faces and character animations feel a bit old and outdated however it is saved by Fable's art direction which still shines though. The game goes for a very classic bedtime story fantasy look, hence the name, and succeeds at it well. It’s a world that takes itself very seriously one minute, and starts poking fun at itself the next. It all manages to work very well; making Albion a world you want to spend time in. This is also helped greatly thanks to the music, which is quite wonderful, perfectly capturing the whimsy the game is throwing at you.For a 10 year old game Fable one holds up surprisingly well. Moral choice in games has certainly grown in the years and in a lot of ways fable feels too simplistic in its decisions to a fault. But at the same time it all works well in the context of its storybook like nature. If you want a fun filled adventure where you get to be the hero, or villain, Fable is still a game worth checking out.

												JUST TO CLARIFY: I have played the Fable series for a long time on the Xbox, ever since it first came out. So my hours don't really reflect how much I have played Fable, let alone the other Fable games (2 and 3).This game has a lot of features and memorable moments (Wont tell you them, no spoilers here). First off, as an RPG, this game balances all the different attributes of a character and how to get them very well. It has a lot of items, a lot of quests, and the main story is over 15 hours, which is a lot more than most games now. The story is also designed very well, and has many memorable moments, as well as a lot of variety in the envirenments. Over all, in a review, I would have to give this game a 9.2/10, but now that it is a very low price, I would give it a 9.7/10 as one of the best singleplayer games on steam.Summary: If you can bear with the older graphics, this game has very good gameplay, story, and has enough side quests to keep you going for hours.

Posted: August 5, 2014
												I missed playing this as kid, having only a playstation, but I must say I am impressed. This is a fun, misleadingly light rpg that draws you in with a neat art style and wit ranging from low brow to high. Playing this game, I realy felt a sense of progression, thanks to the aging and growth system being linked to xp. While it did end up with me being 70 by the time I beat the game, I felt like I had taken a journey as oppossed to completed stages. The lore wasn't particularily deep, as far as I found, anyway, but the game does explain its culture on the way, removing the need to research history on your own. There are karmic paths in game, allowing you to choose how you will behave and in turn how people will treat you. I tried being evil, but I couldn't do it after the second bullying encounter, so I can't say how the dark path is, but the light path like the rest of the game has good progression and meaningful impact on the world. I genuinely enjoyed myself, laughing and tearing up at times, and I highly recomend this game.Now that the anniversary edition is released you may want to play that instead, but I would recommend the nonetheless. 8/10

Posted: December 30, 2014
												Originally I bought this game on the Xbox over a decade ago. I liked my time in the world of Albion so much that I jumped at the chance to buy TLC just so I'd have an excuse to revisit the world, albeit with some welcome changes and additional content that broadened the world and further refined the game play.The Steam release of Fable is thankfully the latter, and it's never been better. The game supports psuedo HD, which is to say that although it runs native at, I believe, 800x600 it can be scaled up to whatever display you require. Much to my delight, widescreen support is also present.Sadly controller support is not available in the vanilla release, but if you felt so inclined there are some readily available mods that place that functionality in there.Many are of the opinion that the first Fable game was the pinnacle of the series, I share in that opinion. Though even if you are new to the series or a returning fan, this game warrants a playthrough. It clocks in at a modest 30 hours, but the real charm of the game is the morality system which tailors events and content of the game to how good or bad you are in interactions or story choices. People may delight in the sight of you just to run to you and cheer, the inverse would have the population of the world running in fear and screaming.The sole complaint I have with this game is that the player character feels a little lifeless. Some of that can be forgiven if you take into account that he's intended to be a cypher for you to project your own emotions upon. Still, it is disheartening to see in the games cutscenes a mute character that for the majority of the game reacts like a wooden playdoll.

Posted: June 19, 2015
												Hra, kterou jsem na prvních pár pokusů nedohrál. Snažil sem se co nejrychleji doběhnout hlavní lini, samozřejmě vedlejší úkoly sem také bral, ale vždycky ve třech čtvrtinách mě hra z nějakého důvodu přestala bavit. Jednoho dne, po asi 20. rozehrání sem si řekl kurňa, tak já teda zkusim koupit barák, udělat manželku, zahrát si hospodský hry, měnit účesy,... A zjistil jsem, že Fable je ještě větší hra, než sem myslel. A to sem si původně myslel, že je pěkně malá, díky ne tak rozlehlým lokacím. Úplně jsem zapoměl na hlavní příběh a užíval si vítězství v hospodách, soutěžích v kopání slepic, sbírání legendárních zbraní, rybaření, hledání pokladů, atd. Hra je na tom jako Morrowind/Oblivion. Musíte mít chuť si jí užít. Osobně jediný zápor, který mi vadil, je ten, že i když už je hrdina v pokročilém věku, lidé na něj pořád mluví jako na fakana a ťuťu ňuňu, no musíš zabít balveriny, kteří trhají vesničany na kousky, yes you do, oh yes you do... Kromě toho nemám námitek.Pro: Pěkné lokace, pěkně vypadající zbraně a brnění, magie, minihry, vedlejší možnosti, zpodobení dobra a zla, místy humorProti: Malé lokace, mluva vesničanů, ne moc kvalitní příběh

Posted: August 31, 2014
												One of the best RPGs of the decade. Simple, yet beautiful. Fable's trademark is the fight between good and evil and the freedom that you, as the main hero, have to choose your own side. You can be evil from start to finish and literaly end the story in tragedy, instead of saving the world for selfish purposes, as it usualy is when you take an evil path in a RPG that has a happy ending regardless of your choices. Beign good, as always, also has its advantages and can be rewarding and fun. You'll feel like finishing the game more than once just to see the differences between playing the good and the bad guy. I've been playing and replaying this game throughout the years and it never gets old.Graphics, animations, gameplay and soundtrack still holds up, nothing feels dated or inadequade, even though the game is already ten years old. If you like action-centered RPGs, this one is for you.Gameplay - 8/10Soundtrack - 8/10Graphics - 7/10Content - 6/10Challenge Level - 3/10Replayability - 4/10

Posted: April 27, 2015
												The best Fable game in the franchise and probably one of the best RPGs I played in early childhood. As an adult I've been able to explore the other sides of the game I ignored and I am still impressed by how they handled the morality system along with player choice. I especially liked the ability to be a homosexual (despite marking the husband as my wife) considering the lack of options in games back then. Overall, this game offers a lot of side quests, weapons (no crafting), spells, and worthwhile plot that still has me in awe considering how much better Jack a villain was compared to the others in the franchise.

Posted: May 16, 2015
												One of the best games i have ever played. I used to watch my brother play it when i was younger and always wanted to play it. Once i got it for the original xbox i completed it over 20 times but never once did i get all the silver keys :3Basically its a role playing game where you can either pick the side of good or evil, every bandit you slay and every trader you punch in the face or cut up accidentally with the cutlass bluetane while trying to hit nymphs makes a difference in terms of weather your good or evil, you kill a bandit and save a bunch of traders through butterfly effect while doing so? You gain good points. You punch a trader in the face because he called you a *annoying runt*? you gain evil points.You feel very free in this game even though the world is reasonably small, The main story line (if you don't take your time like i do) Takes around 13 and a half hours of continuous play including the TLC after-story if its your first time, and only around 5-6 hours if your a pro and you rush it like sanic. The story may feel short but that's only if the story is all that you do, personally i run around killing bandits like a madman and even though i could rush the story if i wanted you don't really get your moneys worth if you do.The story line itself, story wise, is good. The developers clearly put alot of effort into it, unlike me typing this review, and even though its relatively short for someone like me who plays video games for the majority of there life, its long enough for the majority of the populous and the other things to do in albion (the name of the world) more than make up for the short story. To be honest i spent days on my first playthrough however i was very young at the time and after i completed it the first time i started to clear games quite quickly.I love the games mechanics, the combat system is fun and not to hard to use but reasonably difficult to master. The magic isn't over powered whatsoever and the way you level yourself up gives you an amazing sense of achievement even if (like me) your completing the game for the quadrillionth time. They really balanced it perfectly but the glitches really give you an easy time if you chose to exploit them.Now the bugs. The game is solid most of the time and it has a few loading problems every now and then but overall i don't take much notice to that. But the thing they really ♥♥♥♥ up on is the hero save system.Now if you have ever played fable before for longer than one playthrough you would have realized how bugged the herosave system is. Basically if your in the middle of a quest you cant save the game normally, you can only transfer your current hero to a previous save file as to not waste all the time you spent grinding experience in the current quest. however herosaving also transfers items...If you don't see the problem here I'm kinda surprised. By going into a quest and picking up an item of value and then herosaving to before you started the quest you can get infinite of that item. But don't get me wrong, i love this glitch, you can complete the game then herosave to before your first ever quest and complete it again with an over powered character and one shot all the bosses ;DBasically the only "gamebreaking" glitch in the game makes it better and most fans were horrified when they realized the remake had removed it.Its a solid game good gameplay good leveling system and good story. I have no problem with anything in the game except the aging system and as long as you don't abuse the herosave system that doesn't effect you to much anyway.Good luck fighting the final boss on your first run though. xDI rate 9/10, more content would mean the best game of all time for me. Oh yeh and if you know how you can get some of the best late game weapons before the first boss, the game developers really didn't think some of this stuff through.

Posted: March 27, 2014
												Played the first release on the original Xbox and loved the game back then. The art style and colorful characters in this game completely immerse you into its world and storytelling.  "Fable" is one of those games that most people have played, as its been out for so long and has been so highly acclaimed but always had one downfall. It was not long enough. This has been dealt with in "Fable: The Lost Chapters" with so much extra stuff to do within the game, giving more replay value regarding side quests specific to whether you are playing a evil or good character. As well as this, there is a whole new section added to the original ending of the first released game really adding something to the development of the world you have become a part of in playing this game. I felt the need to write a quick review on this game to simply point out, if you've never played a "Fable" game play this one! And if you've played the original definitely play this one, experience that awesome world created in the story along withh all those new things to do!

Posted: July 1, 2013
												TL;DR:The over hyped  Peter Molneux hero simulator. Kick chickens, participate in fight clubs, make black and white morality choices. Realize today why Fable 2/3/journey all suck compared to their grand dad. The new graphical update makes this somewhat obsolete now, so how much is pretty graphics worth really?Pre-face:Most of my play time is on the Xbox version of the game with nearly 13 playthoughs. So this is more of a review of the game, not the steam version.Interesting Tidbits:Peter Molneux started his amazing lying career here. Although, it is not baseless.Pros:(+++) Grow with your character, making him 100% yours(+++) Great sense of humor(+++) Non of that patch later ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, it was released nearly bug free.(+++) Rose tinted glasses(++) A fun morality system (More of a tongue in cheek system)(++) Best villain in any game I've played(++) Controler and keyboard support!(+) Your magica is low, watch that.Cons:(--) Fairly linear(--) The start of the "one button" combat(--) The stupid combat multiplier door(-) I have to murder the whole town to buy the realistate.Conclusion:A all time classic in my book. I'm as biased as it comes with this game, I know it, you know it. Grab this when it goes down to a few bucks and have fun chicken chaser.

Posted: February 16, 2015
												If you are new to RPGs this is a good game to cut your teeth on.First off, I am relatively new to the pick and choose RPG. That said, this was the first one I ever played. Although the graphics look a little dated, it still was a fantastic game that had a good plot. Mind you this game came out before game makers incuded voice acting for the main characters. An enjoyable feature was that you could take parts of all classes and include them in your game for example, you could be a tank that shoots lightning, and then pull out your bow to fight. 												This is definitely a fun, simple game. It's got a cute story, but it's not a huge challenge most of the time. Some of the boss fights are difficult, but not frustratingly so. The aging in this game is interesting; it seems like you are the only person in the world who ages to Professor Farnsworth levels of old, but it's worth a laugh. Posted: January 1, 2015
												I always had heard the general misconception that Fable games are bad, or rather disappointing. I delved into this world looking for high fantasy with no questions asked, and it seemed like the right game for me. I kept seeing people saying 2 and 3 were bad, and that Fable the Lost Chapters was the best in the series, but I was still a bit, if not a lot, hesitant. I doubted and doubted, but I made up my mind and decided to purchase it and play it blind without knowing what is going on. As you may see I yet have to finish the game, but I cannot resist the need to just yell out how great, how excellent this game is. It strives for realism and achieves it in a "videogamey" way. It is action packed and the decisions to be good or evil are very fun. The world does change around you. People hail you if you're good and loathe you if you're evil, even running away from you. You can marry shallow but good-looking characters, and the game even makes fun of itself in this aspect on a book in which it incites you to murder your beloved just because you're bored of him or her. It is great, simply and absurdly great, and it was a real surprise for me to see this game be so good. 9/10 would give a wedding ring to the Guildmaster again.By the way, do not bother with anniversary, play this one, the real one, and see why it doesn't even deserve a remake.

Posted: December 12, 2014
												You should take my review with a big grain of salt because I was only able to play it for such a short while. But the reason for clocking out so soon was that the spinning camera angles gave me a really nasty motion sickness / migraine combo, and that means I can never go back to this game. No game has managed this spectacular feat since the 90's, so it's a huge minus in my book. Probably not a good game choice for anyone who's experienced similar problems with FPS / third person visuals. It's possible I would have endured longer in a console version, but I doubt it.In terms of gameplay, I was also immediately disappointed with... well, pretty much everything. The main character annoyed me from the start and I felt utterly disinclined to watch him grow into an even bigger bundle of annoyingness. Most importantly the hyped moral system was so blatantly black-and-white that it's just a bad joke. Seems to me there's not that much you can do to branch out from that, and I suspect the character changes would be mostly cosmetic.

Posted: September 4, 2014
												I've played Fable in so many ways over so, so many years. I was one of the poor fools waiting years for it to come out, and event hen I was kinda late to the party. All you really need to know is that this game -should- be awful. It failed the hype more than any other game in the history of ever (except maaaybe Duke Nukem Forever, because that one is awful), the graphics were not what they could have been, the combat shouldn't be fun, the voice acting is painful, the story is simplistic, and a few of the design decisions for models still hurt my brain.But the game is wonderful. For all that is 'missing', your mind is happy to fill it in, for all that combat should be a boring slog, every player will try a handful of weird rules and challenges, or, just goof off entirely, and get their fun. Collectibles are at once plentiful, and achievable without aid. Marriage is utterly pointless and unfulfilling. . .that's it, marriage is just pointless and unfulfilling. >.> Meta humor >.> Point is, there is no reason this game should be so awesome, and that's why it stands out as the shining beacon of "See here! This is what matters!" - Aesthetics. Every individual piece seems mismatched, disjointed, and frankly lacklustre on its own. Put them together and. . .you know the rest. Personally, I find this games sits with precious few others on that point of pure aesthetic gold, and among western-produced RPGs? It almost stands alone. Backing away from cartoonishness severely damaged the franchise, and I really do place 90% of the blame on that alone. I'm serious. If they remade Fable III, the exact game, but with Fable's graphics (and more important, use of graphics)? It'd be fine. Tho the♥♥♥♥♥♥♥map, weird hero retreat thing, and those damned guild seals to unlock chests vs. the old xp system would still be huge marrs, I think we could forgive a lot more if the game had just been charming. I'm buying Anniversary because I have to see it first hand. . . but looking at the screenshots honestly reminds me of when I heard the interview about how they finally had the tech to render lifelike creations in Phantom Menace, and used that to make Jar Jar Binks. . . . . What you do with what you got matters a helluva lot more . .tho I never liked Star Wars as a franchise because it's aesthetic has never appealed to me (too much metal >.>), and all it has to offer is the EXACT Hero's Journey, in space, with Buddhism. No thanks. I'll go read Saiyuki.

Posted: August 18, 2014
												I had the CD version of Fable TLC several years ago. I don't know what happened to it. I'm pretty sure it was on 4 or 5 CD's. I remember having problems with it crashing a lot. But I also remember really enjoying it. I was very pleased when the Steam version was released. However I was dismayed to discover that it is still as unstable as I remember it being on my old Pentium 4 several years back. Despite having to give up on the game because of the endless crashes, I would still recommend this game to anybody that can get it to run without the frequent crashes to desktop that I have experienced on a system comprising of a 3GHZ i5 2500K, 8GB DDR3 RAM and an HD7870 2GB running Windows 7 64bit.I'm extremely pleased that the game is being re-released in the remastered Aniversary Edition that is due out in September of this year. Posted: December 31, 2013
												I loved this game when I had it on Xbox. I have heard and seen it as being one of the most disapointing games of it's time, but I loved it. I went into the game blind, and loved it. I think it was because it was expected to be much more, but I was very happy where it was. It had plenty of action, a good story, great characters, and a lot of humor. It had a quite ElderScrolls feel to the leveling up. Instead of like most RPGs, where you get EXP from killing enemies and used that to level up, Fable is a bit different. You do get EXP from killing, but you also get it from doing the killing. You shoot something with an arrow, you get skill EXP. Blast them with lightning, you get will EXP. Bash them with a hammer, you get strength EXP. They do not mix together, so you can't play as pure mage and have a high health. Not from Will EXP, at least. This is where the General EXP come in, the stuff you get from killing and quests. That can be put towards anything. Also, what you do in the game effects your appearence. Like to crunch on little newborn chickens (yes, you can do that) and kill people? A red mist will rise from your feet and eyes, you will become pale, flies will be drawn to you like the corpses you leave behind, and you grow horns (also destroying the majority of your hairstyle). People will run in terror from you, and hate you though your power will keep them from doing anything. But if you play as good, people will flock to, you will get a halo and a beam of light when you stand still. I think your eyes change color, though it has been a long time. Max out strength and you will look like a bodybuilder. Will will make you glow. I can't remember what Skill does. Fighting badly leaves you with scars.I could keep going on, but you should play it yourself. My only complaints are that the GuildMaster gets annoying "Your health is low. Have you any potions, or food", and I am having trouble getting the game to run on my computer even though it should be able to run it no problem. But once I get it up and running I won't be doing much else.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												This remake and extension is second to none.  The graphics for a game from (technically) 2004 are extremely good and fit the entire aura the game tries to create. If you're not familiar with the Fable franchise, you essentially experience the life of a hero but also mould and shape his reputation and stature within the town. You are faced with many problems that need solving either through being 'good' or 'bad'. These decisions affect the story-line, those around you and even the town itself. The Lost Chapters offers new content as the story continues from where the game ended in the original version, giving you hours of fun. Not only is the playability of this game exceptional, it also has a great feel to it and feels natural when in combat etc. This makes combat fun and not tiresome despite some repetitve enemies and repetitive movements. The AI in combat are actually pretty smart which adds to the fun, they can dodge, block and counter, often making it difficult to hurt them... not too challenging, but challenging enough for a fun battle with every encounter. The length of the game is not bad at all, it should take you around 10-11 hours to complete the game with minimal exploring... whilst this is significantly shorter than the following titles, this captivating story is definitely worth at least a run through. It's the sort of game you want to play again and again, doing things differently each time and seeing how that affects your hero and also those around you. I'm currently on my fourth time round this game (just on this platform) and not bored even in the slightest. In regards to the other Fable titles, I'd say they're all equally awesome and enthralling. If I had to pick an absolute favourite it would have to be Fable 2. Yet, this game is almost up there and transitions you well throughout each game if you follow the titles from the start up, seeing the development of this game is very rewarding. I just hope Fable 2 is released on Steam, that would be rad. The look and feel of this game is beautiful, a well designed game with everything thought out well. The world in which you immerse yourself is visually stunning and very light-hearted, often bright and alluring, however, when evil forces are around the sky will turn grey and there will be a shift in atmosphere. The game creates atmosphere very well utilising the scenery, lighting and music. A nice touch for an aged game is the aging of your character over the course of the story and also his metamorphosis into an angel-like figure or devil-like figure (dependant on the path you choose). This really does immerse you into the game and gets you emotionally involved with your character and creates a synthetic relationship as you've essentially been with him is whole life and shaped the man he is today. A final note is the sound work with the game; excellent. Nice voice acting and nice sound effects and the soundtrack of the game is very fitting and gives you a nice warm sense of adventure as you delve into the world of Fable. Definitely pick up this game! Pros:-Visually stunning and captivating.- You shape how the game is played. - Enticing narrative which emotionally invloves you well.- Great voice acting and great atmosphere held throughout. Cons:-Not Fable 2.9.5 out of 10 for me.

Posted: May 16, 2015
												One of the best games i have ever played. I used to watch my brother play it when i was younger and always wanted to play it. Once i got it for the original xbox i completed it over 20 times but never once did i get all the silver keys :3Basically its a role playing game where you can either pick the side of good or evil, every bandit you slay and every trader you punch in the face or cut up accidentally with the cutlass bluetane while trying to hit nymphs makes a difference in terms of weather your good or evil, you kill a bandit and save a bunch of traders through butterfly effect while doing so? You gain good points. You punch a trader in the face because he called you a *annoying runt*? you gain evil points.You feel very free in this game even though the world is reasonably small, The main story line (if you don't take your time like i do) Takes around 13 and a half hours of continuous play including the TLC after-story if its your first time, and only around 5-6 hours if your a pro and you rush it like sanic. The story may feel short but that's only if the story is all that you do, personally i run around killing bandits like a madman and even though i could rush the story if i wanted you don't really get your moneys worth if you do.The story line itself, story wise, is good. The developers clearly put alot of effort into it, unlike me typing this review, and even though its relatively short for someone like me who plays video games for the majority of there life, its long enough for the majority of the populous and the other things to do in albion (the name of the world) more than make up for the short story. To be honest i spent days on my first playthrough however i was very young at the time and after i completed it the first time i started to clear games quite quickly.I love the games mechanics, the combat system is fun and not to hard to use but reasonably difficult to master. The magic isn't over powered whatsoever and the way you level yourself up gives you an amazing sense of achievement even if (like me) your completing the game for the quadrillionth time. They really balanced it perfectly but the glitches really give you an easy time if you chose to exploit them.Now the bugs. The game is solid most of the time and it has a few loading problems every now and then but overall i don't take much notice to that. But the thing they really ♥♥♥♥ up on is the hero save system.Now if you have ever played fable before for longer than one playthrough you would have realized how bugged the herosave system is. Basically if your in the middle of a quest you cant save the game normally, you can only transfer your current hero to a previous save file as to not waste all the time you spent grinding experience in the current quest. however herosaving also transfers items...If you don't see the problem here I'm kinda surprised. By going into a quest and picking up an item of value and then herosaving to before you started the quest you can get infinite of that item. But don't get me wrong, i love this glitch, you can complete the game then herosave to before your first ever quest and complete it again with an over powered character and one shot all the bosses ;DBasically the only "gamebreaking" glitch in the game makes it better and most fans were horrified when they realized the remake had removed it.Its a solid game good gameplay good leveling system and good story. I have no problem with anything in the game except the aging system and as long as you don't abuse the herosave system that doesn't effect you to much anyway.Good luck fighting the final boss on your first run though. xDI rate 9/10, more content would mean the best game of all time for me. Oh yeh and if you know how you can get some of the best late game weapons before the first boss, the game developers really didn't think some of this stuff through.

Posted: January 14, 2013
												Fable is an RPG that has a strong emphasis on choosing your path as good or evil.  Every quest has some sort of consequence that gives you points towards the two.  The fighting in the game, while sometimes frustrating, is enjoyable with many skills unlockable to the player.  The fighting, however awesome it maybe, also has some frustrations as I sometimes felt like the enemy could attack much faster than I ever could block or get out of the way.  The story is solid but expect a shorter than usual experience as this one only lasts about 16 hours - with the Lost Chapters adding about 2 - round the total for both the main game + expansion right at 18 hours.  The upside to this is it allows you to re-play and do the story through the other side of the coin and see how your actions affect the world and those you interact with.  Highly recommend!

Posted: August 11, 2014
												Hello there! If you're reading this, you're looking for a review on Fable: TLC, and i aim to please you with such.Fable - The Lost Chapters ( Fable:TLC for short) is the PC-Port of the game Fable 1 with added content & storyline, which also got released on the Xbox slightly after, the game focuses on being an action third player person view game which allows you to roleplay and costumize your character(hero) whether it be through skill, personality or appearance in various different ways.Throughout the entire game, you'll be given choices of which are categorized by beither either "good" or "evil", and by doing said actions, you gain points for each one, being evil will modify your character's visual look and make him look visibly like a demon, otherwise, by doing good, you'll have a halo on your head, and your hair will turn white alongside having butterflies fly around you.Do these actions actually matter towards the storyline? Yes, they do, you're given different cutscenes depending on what path you take and certain things change in the game as well as having different spells you can master.I'll be appointing each section a numerical value between 1 and 10 to make it easier and to allow quick TL;DR for those who don't really care for the in-depth review.-- Graphics --  (7/10)The game was originally released in 2004, then had it's expansion released in the later year of 2005, i'd state the graphics are very good for it's age and that they do not look bad at all, even if you think that way, the game is quite customizable and you can use mods to enchance your gameplay performance. ( There's also Fable:TLC Anniversary on Xbox now.)Are there any bugs regarding the graphics? Very little, you may experience some errors occasionally regarding character glows or weapon glows or entering a new area and the loading being awkward, but nothing out of the extraordinary.The game brings widescreen support so you also don't have to worry yourself about any of the screens bigger than 4:3 ratio.Some may be annoyed by the character's textures, but i think they look fine for the age of which the game was produced.-- Gameplay -- (7/10)The initial parts of the game hold very little action as it is showing you the storyplot, but as soon as you're done with the "Wasp Queen" quest, you'll start to frequently experience more and more action.The gameplay is very action-based and revolves around you as a hero focusing on the utilization of three main powerpoints, Strength, Skill(Speed, accuracy and stealth) and Will( Magical prowess), you spend points on these throughout the gmae in order to improve your character's statistics.Similarily to an MMO, the way to gain those points is by killing enemies, or doing quests, which will gain you "experience points", points that can be used to tap in all three of the major areas, or you can utilize specific points to each one.Ingame, you're given the option of going in full melee, sitting back with a bow or utilizing magic to enchance yourself, or a mixture of all of them, i believe that they did the variation very well and that there's no real downsides here, at times the characters may be able to hit you through awkward hitboxes, but that doesn't happen frequently.You may experience annoyance at the GuildMaster's constant bickering if you do not heal your Will/HP energy points up by either eating/utilizing a potion.NPC spawns are predictable and very rarely change with area when it comes to the enemy AI, they mostly repeat the same process over and over, HOWEVER, the AI is not to be underestimated as it is quite random and at times it will DECIDE to hit you when you least expect it, or block attacks and counter-attack you back, so it does increase the difficulty and i say kudos on this.For some, the game will be considered quite easy, and you will most likely not die a single time, the replay value in the gameplay is very high, so you can consider re-doing the game and even imposing challenges on yourself, or doing the "boasting" challenges that they grant you for each quest after the starter ones, allowing you to effectively increase the skill-cap required. ( Begins at the Orchard Farm quest).Weapon variety is high, from a numerous amount of 1handed weapons, 2 handed, and allowing you to even change between crossbows and bows for ranged endeavors, the modding is also well open and allows the modification of weapons to create new custom-content or even apply other character weapons into your own.Same applies for customization, you can customize your character in any way you'd like, ranging from tatoos, different titles, armor, mixing armor parts( boots, shirt, etc) and all sorts of fun stuff. IE: You CAN get drunk in this game or become fat, and there are various mini-games, easter eggs,jokes & Demon doors along the way so that the gameplay is not constantly filling your face with action, same for the side-quests which allow you to take a small break from the main one.You can abuse certain points of the game to get your character stronger than it should be at the current time or grab items that you otherwise would have difficulty having through the "Hero Save" option, or by utilizing a trader glitch that allows you to gain more everytime you buy and resell specific items at the early stages of the game allowing you to rack up a large amount of gold. But these do not necessarily break the game for me, and you can choose not to utilize them in the first place as they were player-created.More on the "Hero Saving", you have two types of save, a "World" save in which it saves your current position and everything you hold, and a "Hero Save" which saves your items currently held and puts you at the initial scene of the quest, you MAY not save your location ingame during an ongoing quest which may annoy some.A trait that may be annoying for some is the aging system which is based on your skill progress.(age increases as you level skills)Others may get bored out of the action-combat due to having too much experience with the game, however the replay value is great even then.   -- Performance -- (8/10)The game's performance is great, it works even on older PCS with outdated graphic cards, and it has many numerous options in order to tone down the graphics, i did not feel at any time any moment of which i had a drop of FPS.The game is compatible with different types of OS so you do not need to worry about having Vista, XP or Windows 7, as they all work.There is a slight problem in that the game will SOMETIMES CRASH unexpectely and for unknown reasons, or simply NOT play Audio clips at times it should, however it does have a safe-mode itself and you can usually run that if you run into any performance issues. -- Audio -- (6/10)The OST is decent, i feel as though it could've been better and it is lacking in a lot of fighting scenes / cutcenes, the ones that do have it are fitting though, nothing majorly special.-- General -- (7/10)I believe the game is quite legendary for it's time, even if you dislike it or hate it, it has created a giant fanbase and was one of the best prequels imagineable for the Fable series, many people to this day still prefer Fable:TLC over Fable II &  Fable III.I would recommend this game to anyone who wants a game with a lot of fighting & magic, but at the same time wants to roleplay, enjoy himself and fascinate himself with the good story plot that it provides, making full use of the unique story-dialogue cutscenes given to you.( they may be boring for some but i for one love them)It is a must-buy for any RPG-lover and if it's on sale i would definitely say get it as it's worth every penny unless you are not into the genre.Thanks for reading this review, and i hope that gave you a good idea of what the game is like, allowing you to reconsider and ponder your opinion on whether to get it.

Posted: January 28, 2014
												Fable is a franchise I've had a bit of a rocky relationship with. My first experience was Fable II (having completely missed the original), and it is one of my favorite games of the Xbox 360 era. Fable III, not so much. With Fable Anniversary coming out soon, the remake of the now 10 year old RPG, I figured why not just get a cheap copy of the original and see what it’s all about. The premise starts you as a young boy in the town of Oakvale in the land of Albion, who has a loving sister and parents. But that kind of story makes for a boring video game, so a group of bandits attack your village, kidnaping your mother and sister, and murdering practically everyone else, including your father. But before you meet your own demise, you’re saved by a hero named Maze, and are inducted into the Guild of Heroes. In the world of Albion, a hero isn't just a title but an occupation, something you learn by joining the guild. The game switches over to your teenage years for your guild training and then finally to adulthood after you become a true hero. This is the first neat trick Fable does, giving your character, and the world, a real sense of growth. Seeing the world change around you as you grow and make choices is neat, and gives everything a sense of place.Fable has the typical “your character glows if they’re good and pale skin and devil horns if you’re evil” that most games with morality like to do, but how you spec your character also affects them. If you put a bunch of points into strength, your character will become more bulky and muscular as a result, while if you put a lot of points into magic, you get glowing blue tattoos on your face. Unfortunately the options felt a bit too simple preventing me from having my character look exactly how I want. I like my characters to be a bit on the thin and scrawny side, probably because I myself am thin and scrawny, but there wasn't any way to go full on melee combat without forcing yourself to become a hulking beast. A little more variety on this front would have been cool.In combat your main tool will be your melee, of which you are given a nice selection of fast swords like the katana, something with a bit more punch like great swords, and even more massive weapons like hammers. There’s not much in the ways of multiple attacks, it’s rather simplistic with one button for attacking and another for using a flourish attack when you build one up. It’s all about timing and avoiding your enemies with blocks and dodges. Getting in hits and avoiding them yourself builds up your combat multiplier, letting you deal more damage. It’s a system that works but by the end of the game I found myself a little tired of it. The ranged combat, bows and crossbows, I found to be rather useless. It has its place in certain situations but you’re not going to want to spec your character into a full ranged one, which is a disappointment. Magic is by far the most interesting and varied. There’s a ton of spells all put into a bunch of categories. So if you want to go full on attack magic you can throw points into lighting, fire, etc. Even if you’re melee focused like I was, it’s worth getting spells like slow time, which I found invaluable during the later parts of the game.The core of Fable has you taking on guild quests, making choices, and being the "hero." The moral choice system is bit too black and white for my tastes. You’re never really given any grey area and it’s always very clear which is good and which is evil. Having a character say something like, "you can go do this quest for this reward, or I guess if you were some sort of evil person you could always just kill me," doesn't really leave much to the imagination. One nice thing however is the game does provide full good and full evil side quests, usually having them be on opposite sides of the same problem. Will you take the quest the farmers put up to help stop the bandit raids, or will you take the quest the bandits put up to help with the raid. Stuff like that’s more fun because it lets you put your intentions forward right away rather than giving you some black and white choice half way through the quest.Another big component of the game is the interaction system with NPCs. You hero has a ton of different emotions they can express ranging from simple ones like laughing or saying hi, too more morality specific ones like flexing your heroic muscles or giving an evil laugh, too the ridiculously absurd such as farting and doing the chicken dance. Sadly I never found myself having any real gameplay reason to use them past their first time. For example you can flirt with NPCs and eventually have them fall in love with you. Cool idea, but no real benefit doing it. I didn't even have to try honestly. By the end of the game, every girl, and even some men, had a big enough heart above them that I could simply walk up to them, hand them a wedding ring, and be married before the sun set without even trying. The ability to interact with NPCs is a neat idea, and admittedly I got excited when they started to call me by my title I picked out and talking about past quests I did, but overall it feels more like a proof of concept than a fully implemented feature.The story does go to some interesting places and has a large focus on family, with the hero's sister and mother coming heavily into play. This does give everything a more personal feel to it and I found myself caring in the hero's journey and his seeking revenge. The antagonist, Jack of Blades, lives up to his awesome name by being a great creepy villain. My only wish was that is motivations were explained better as I was never quite sure why he was doing what he was doing other than to just be evil.It’s worth noting that I played the PC version, known as Fable: The Lost Chapters, which contains a bunch of extra characters, side quests, and continues the story after the final boss battle, which by the way was pretty weak. The extra content is cool, adding new characters and extra story that is welcome, but doesn't feel completely necessary. Also the new final boss somehow manages to be easier and lamer than the original.Graphically the game holds up pretty well for being 10 years old. Stuff like faces and character animations feel a bit old and outdated however it is saved by Fable's art direction which still shines though. The game goes for a very classic bedtime story fantasy look, hence the name, and succeeds at it well. It’s a world that takes itself very seriously one minute, and starts poking fun at itself the next. It all manages to work very well; making Albion a world you want to spend time in. This is also helped greatly thanks to the music, which is quite wonderful, perfectly capturing the whimsy the game is throwing at you.For a 10 year old game Fable one holds up surprisingly well. Moral choice in games has certainly grown in the years and in a lot of ways fable feels too simplistic in its decisions to a fault. But at the same time it all works well in the context of its storybook like nature. If you want a fun filled adventure where you get to be the hero, or villain, Fable is still a game worth checking out.

Posted: June 20, 2014
												Judging Fable’s qualities as a video game, both then and now, is a relatively easy thing to do. But trying to come to a conclusion about this game as a whole is a lot more difficult. Playing the original game again the raw ambition is still obvious, but inevitably many of its best ideas have now been appropriated by other games. And, equally inevitably, most of those other games have managed to fashion a more consistently enjoyable experience out of them.I got this game mainly due to the fact I like RPGs and there are little available for the 360. Part of my gripe with Fable is largely due to the emmulation of the 360 console as opposed to the game itself however, Fable still has some irritating aspects which I'll cover first.On the subject of the actual emmulation, the game requires at least 2 or 3 updates to be installed every time I put the game on which is a bit annoying although undertstandable. However, the emmulation at time causes my game to freeze which takes me onto my next point regarding the game.The save procedure can be infuriating. While for the most part you can complete a "world" save which stores everything you've done you can't do this mid quest. All you can complete is a "hero" save which stores you're experience but not how far you are in the quest. Bearing in mind some quests are very long winded, and during this you do a lot of battling. What really annoyed me was getting half way through one, then going into a different area of Albion only to find my game freezes on the load page leaving me to restart the console. That also meant that I was back to square 1 with the quests.

Posted: February 24, 2013
												The first game in the Fable franchise, and my favorite. The gameplay can be compared to Elderscrolls, but with a more ballanced approach to gameplay. Stat's are raized by experience (divided up depending on how you kill your enemies), but farther along in the game there isn't really anything keeping you from specializing in all three areas (Strength, Skill (dexterity), and Magic). The idea of Good and Evil play's an important part in the story, allowing you to be either admired or feared. The Lost Chapters is an extention to your story, bringing you to a new land with new adventures. The comedy in the game is carried out through hilarious dialogue, while still maintaining a serrious main storyline. For those who long for a great Action RPG from the past, this is the one for you!

Posted: June 30, 2014
												This remake and extension is second to none.  The graphics for a game from (technically) 2004 are extremely good and fit the entire aura the game tries to create. If you're not familiar with the Fable franchise, you essentially experience the life of a hero but also mould and shape his reputation and stature within the town. You are faced with many problems that need solving either through being 'good' or 'bad'. These decisions affect the story-line, those around you and even the town itself. The Lost Chapters offers new content as the story continues from where the game ended in the original version, giving you hours of fun. Not only is the playability of this game exceptional, it also has a great feel to it and feels natural when in combat etc. This makes combat fun and not tiresome despite some repetitve enemies and repetitive movements. The AI in combat are actually pretty smart which adds to the fun, they can dodge, block and counter, often making it difficult to hurt them... not too challenging, but challenging enough for a fun battle with every encounter. The length of the game is not bad at all, it should take you around 10-11 hours to complete the game with minimal exploring... whilst this is significantly shorter than the following titles, this captivating story is definitely worth at least a run through. It's the sort of game you want to play again and again, doing things differently each time and seeing how that affects your hero and also those around you. I'm currently on my fourth time round this game (just on this platform) and not bored even in the slightest. In regards to the other Fable titles, I'd say they're all equally awesome and enthralling. If I had to pick an absolute favourite it would have to be Fable 2. Yet, this game is almost up there and transitions you well throughout each game if you follow the titles from the start up, seeing the development of this game is very rewarding. I just hope Fable 2 is released on Steam, that would be rad. The look and feel of this game is beautiful, a well designed game with everything thought out well. The world in which you immerse yourself is visually stunning and very light-hearted, often bright and alluring, however, when evil forces are around the sky will turn grey and there will be a shift in atmosphere. The game creates atmosphere very well utilising the scenery, lighting and music. A nice touch for an aged game is the aging of your character over the course of the story and also his metamorphosis into an angel-like figure or devil-like figure (dependant on the path you choose). This really does immerse you into the game and gets you emotionally involved with your character and creates a synthetic relationship as you've essentially been with him is whole life and shaped the man he is today. A final note is the sound work with the game; excellent. Nice voice acting and nice sound effects and the soundtrack of the game is very fitting and gives you a nice warm sense of adventure as you delve into the world of Fable. Definitely pick up this game! Pros:-Visually stunning and captivating.- You shape how the game is played. - Enticing narrative which emotionally invloves you well.- Great voice acting and great atmosphere held throughout. Cons:-Not Fable 2.9.5 out of 10 for me.

												This game is fantastic. Definitely one of my top 5 of all-time.The graphics are wonderful for it's time and even know. The voice acting is spectacular. The combat is insanely fun. And the story is wonderful. This is a linear world RPG game. It's not an open world like Skyrim, more like Knights of the Old Republic or Jade Empire which is very nice.In terms of combat, you can use swords and axes, bows and crossbows and lastly magic. The magic abilities are really awesome and some of my favorites of all-time. Unfortunately, there are no staves whatsoever for you mages out there. There aren't a whole of items in terms of apparel. I did not find this a problem, why? Because the few items you can get are AWESOME and very beautiful. Examples are mage robes, armour and basic civilian attire.This game is very easy. Not difficult at all. You will probably never die and once be stumped in this game. It is seriously just a hack and slash game. There is only one boss where even the least bit of strategy is involed to kill him. In a sense, making it a hack and slash, but it's not a bad thing at all because this game makes combat fun. Decapations and shooting peoples heads off are some of the best.You can get drunk, get married, own a ♥♥♥♥♥ house and even your own bar. Cool right? Right. Though these things don't have a huge impact on you whatsoever, this is one of the earliest RPGs that allowed you to do some of those things..well..,mainly the ♥♥♥♥♥ house. Ha. You can even rent your homes to people and get extra gold, cha-ching! If that's not enough, you can gain trophies from completing quests and show them off to raise your renown level!  Gold, health and mana are very easy to come by. It's very convenient. This is honestly one of the ONLY RPGs I was not afraid to be a spellcaster with. I usually fret in most games because you always seem to run out of mana at the most unconvenient times, am I right? Well not this game! They are everywhere and it's great. I loved killing the masses of undead heading my way with lighting, or using my infernal wrath to conjure up a circular energy on the ground to stop them in there tracks and completely obliterate them. It's the small things, ya know?The story is beautiful and you can't wait to see what happens next, even though the story is short. To 100% this game, it takes 15 hours max. Then again, I've beaten this game about 8 times. 100% also including upgrading ALL your skills (which again, a lot of games don't allow you to do that as well) collecting all the dolls from mini-games and books as well. In all reality, this game is very small, but it packs so much awesomeness that it's forgiveable.Becoming evil allows you to grow horns and have flies hanging around you 24/7. As fun as being evil can be, I'm not a big fan of the hairloss. Being good looks awesome as well, having a halo and a blue light surrounding you is nice. Speaking of which, tattoos and beards! These actually effect you in a big way. If you have that scary tattoo, you'll have the females and males yelping and bolting out of the sigh of your presence. Having a nice hair and stache and the ladies and gents will dig you, a lot. Sexual orientation is really awesome as well. You can really be  who you want..minus a female because you have to be a male in this game.Honestly, I could speak of how wonderful this game is for hours. It's just..for me, that game that I'll always be able to recommend and talk about. It's just a great experience and if you have a little over half a day or need to pull an allnight for whatever reason. Make this your go to game and go slave some balvarians and win the arena! Do yourself a favor and check this game out.

Posted: January 4, 2014
												 I have to say I wasn't to exited to play this game when I first started. I previously played Fable III and only bought the game after hearing the poplar complaint that Fable II and III had failed to live up standards of the first game. Firstly,  the opening tutorial was painful at times and the graphics are not the best thing this game has to offer, but once you get past that, Fable: The Lost Chapters is a truly enjoyable game. The combat system is fluid for melee, ranged, and magic alike, the leveling/experience system rewards you XP for not only defeating monsters and completing quest but also for which skills you used to do so. For explain, if I used magic abilities, whether they be combative or not, I would receive Magic XP, which I then could spend on buying or upgrading my magical talents.  Thus the more I use my skills, the better I will be at those skills. Another feature I liked was the ability to Boast. Just after you take a quest you have the ability to Boast about what you will do on said quest, for explain doing the entire quest with no clothes or without taking or doing damage, doing so increases gold you will receive at the completion of the quest while also providing a challenge for the journey ahead.  In order to truly get the Fable experience and better understand the series you must give this game a try.

Posted: December 21, 2013
												I played Fable on the Original Xbox almost a decade ago and back then I stated that Fable was "the best game I had ever played"- of course, better games have come along since then and have swept that title away from Fable's grasp, but that doesn't demote the fact that this game is an absolute masterpiece not only for its time, but by todays standards too.I'm sort of nervous writing this "review"- not because I fear the criticism I may get in return for creating it because I doubt they'll be any, but more for the fact that I want this game to get the good review it deserves as I absolutely adore this game, nonetheless, let me get into why. Unlike most RPG's that force you to go down one linear path, Fable grants you the freedom to set which moral allignment you want to persue which  will determine how you look visually and how people will treat you. If you chose to be evil, you will grow horns, flies will start to fly around you and villagers will boo and scream when they see you however if you chose to be good, you will grow a halo, butterflies will start to fly around you and villagers will cheer and compliment you when they see you- it's the tiny details that come together to make this game great. One thing I must critisize is the lack of sublety when making a moral decision, sometimes it can be so obvious that it's just "press the LMB to be good and the RMB to be evil", which although it's still nice to be given the option, could of be relayed in a better way to the player. The quests are actually interesting and never feel like a grind, gracefully not following the usual way of modern RPGs in the sense that all the work goes into the main questline and the side quests are just "kill, fetch and return". The characters are memorable and will stick with you throughout the game. The storyline, although starting to get slightly confusing halfway through, is still gripping. If you've watched any videos about Peter Molyneux preaching Fable by lying and building it up to be better than what it is, then I'd understand why you'd be disappointed playing the game, however if you haven't and have just stumbled upon this review either by accident or by sheer curiousity, I'm almost certain that if you're an avid fan of RPG's that this will become one of your favourites for life.

Posted: March 31, 2014
												This game is truly amazing, I freakin' love it! In my opinion, this is the only truly impressive game in the Fable series. In this game you play as The Hero Of Oakvale, a young child with dreams of greatness. The game sees you grow from a young punk, into a daring hero, dark warrior, or powerful mage. You can be anything you want in the game, you can even be a naked guy who runs around murdering people with a pic-axe! The game has fairly good graphics for the time, and I think they've aged fairly well.This game's soundtrack is one of the best soundtracks I've heard in an RPG! The theme tune was done by the amazing Danny Elfman, the same guy who did the music for the Spiderman trilogy and The Simpsons. The game allows true character evolution, as your character will evolve depending upon what skills you choose to focus on and your chosen allignment. For example, if you focus on building your strength skills you will become a big muscly giant. If you focus on being a good guy, you will look like Super Saiyan Goku. The game allows you to be whatever you want, and that's what I enjoy.The game does have problems though, and I'm going to avoid talking about the false advertising, because everyone has already bashed on it. One of the main annoyances I've had with the game is it's difficulty. It's way too easy, seriously! Five hours into the game and I'm able to bat everything away with zero effort! Almost all of the magic spells are overpowered and break the game. Do yourself a favor and avoid getting the Slow Time spell, it will kill any fun you can have. On top of that, there are various exploits in the game to get more powerful in a short amount of time. One such example is that the game features Ages potions, which give you a fair boost in EXP in a certain skill tree.The problem? If you have your combat multiplier up high enough and drink the potion, you'll get mad EXP for almost nothing! I had my combat multiplier at 14 and drank a potion, and got 14800 EXP in the will category! Also, the story was fairly predictable at times, and some of the characters seemed flat. I never really liked Briar Rose all that much, and Maze was just lame to me. I'd like Guildmaster more if he didn't pipe random advice into my ear every five seconds. And I found that some sidequests were either really lame, or didn't off much reward. One such quest is one where I have to acquire for blue mushrooms to cure a sick child, but the reward wasn't really that great in the grand scheme of things.Despite all that, I highly reccomend this game! If you're new to open-world RPGs and are on the fence of getting into these kinds of games, Fable would be a good starter for you. It isn't as large or as immerssive as Oblivon, Fallout 3, or Kingdoms Of Amalur, but you'll still get some bang out of your buck. Fable introduced me to the world of action RPGs, and I will never regret buying this game used back in the day. When this game goes on sale, I highly suggest picking it up. One final thing to note: This game does not have a difficulty slider, so you're stuck with the preset difficulty. Like said, it's easy but totally worth the price tag.

Posted: June 27, 2014
												At first glance this game just looks like your average RPG, but further research shows that it is much much more than that. First off in Fable every character has enormous hands and feet, don't let this turn you off, and really small teeth. The game looks great for something that was released 10 years ago that is if you're okay with original xbox level graphics. The game feels natural once you learn all of the controls but if you're playing on a laptop GET A MOUSE or else the game will be frustrating to the max. The music in this game is just generic RPG music so don't expect to be blown away by fully orchestrated tracks. Also the voices in this game are laughably bad for example many NPCs speak with a cocny accent which really grinds my gears, but that's just me. In addition to that whenever your health is low an old man nags you to eat food or use a healing potion, yeah I heard you the first time just let me live my life. While this game is no Zeld: Ocarina of Time it's a fun jaunt into an unoriginal fantasy world. Get it whenever it's on sale, you may or may not be sorry.
