Posted: February 12, 2012
												Very rarely do I play role-playing games and even rarer do I complete them. Fable, an above average game of that particular genre, is one that knows not to overstay its welcome.Like many other role-playing games that have come before and after, gameplay revolves around gaining experience by completing quests and slaying enemies. While leveling up, you may invest in one of three attributes: magic, melee, and ranged combat. It's always exciting to see your character progress from an underling to a skilled warrior of sorts.Unfortunately, Fable's combat system could use some improvements. The blocking mechanism seems completely useless as many enemies will give no indication of when they attack.Fable is the kind of game in which, to enjoy its full experience, requires at least two playthroughs. I'd expect good and evil choices to result in drastically different consequences. Maybe I'll update this review if I ever replay Fable. Nonetheless, this comes highly recommended!Grade: B

Posted: November 30, 2014
												Fable is a game about one thing - beating the snot out of everything in sight.  Many will say that it is supposed to be about choice, but in reality the choices don't matter aside from giving you specific weapons (or constantly having the village guards on you about simply existing).  Beat up enemies, search for relics to increase your power, do quests to increase your influence, follow the storyline.  Rinse, repeat.In terms of environment I'd prefer a game similar to Dragon Quest 8 or The Elder Scrolls for this type of gameplay.  The world is segregated by zones and paths between them rather than an open world you are able to get lost in, quickly quashing any feeling of freedom in exploration you would otherwise have in the game.Freedom in building your character, on the other hand, is much closer to the other end of the spectrum.  You can play as a melee weapon strength user, a ranged weapon skill user, or a physics-bending will user.  Or, if you want to put another 100 or so hours into the game, you can do all three and make yourself nearly untouchable.  Tons of melee weapons, ranged weapons, and spells make any of the three viable - but ultimately you'll be building these up by beating the snot out of everything in sight.

Posted: June 29, 2014
												This game is fantastic. Definitely one of my top 5 of all-time.The graphics are wonderful for it's time and even know. The voice acting is spectacular. The combat is insanely fun. And the story is wonderful. This is a linear world RPG game. It's not an open world like Skyrim, more like Knights of the Old Republic or Jade Empire which is very nice.In terms of combat, you can use swords and axes, bows and crossbows and lastly magic. The magic abilities are really awesome and some of my favorites of all-time. Unfortunately, there are no staves whatsoever for you mages out there. There aren't a whole of items in terms of apparel. I did not find this a problem, why? Because the few items you can get are AWESOME and very beautiful. Examples are mage robes, armour and basic civilian attire.This game is very easy. Not difficult at all. You will probably never die and once be stumped in this game. It is seriously just a hack and slash game. There is only one boss where even the least bit of strategy is involed to kill him. In a sense, making it a hack and slash, but it's not a bad thing at all because this game makes combat fun. Decapations and shooting peoples heads off are some of the best.You can get drunk, get married, own a ♥♥♥♥♥ house and even your own bar. Cool right? Right. Though these things don't have a huge impact on you whatsoever, this is one of the earliest RPGs that allowed you to do some of those things..well..,mainly the ♥♥♥♥♥ house. Ha. You can even rent your homes to people and get extra gold, cha-ching! If that's not enough, you can gain trophies from completing quests and show them off to raise your renown level!  Gold, health and mana are very easy to come by. It's very convenient. This is honestly one of the ONLY RPGs I was not afraid to be a spellcaster with. I usually fret in most games because you always seem to run out of mana at the most unconvenient times, am I right? Well not this game! They are everywhere and it's great. I loved killing the masses of undead heading my way with lighting, or using my infernal wrath to conjure up a circular energy on the ground to stop them in there tracks and completely obliterate them. It's the small things, ya know?The story is beautiful and you can't wait to see what happens next, even though the story is short. To 100% this game, it takes 15 hours max. Then again, I've beaten this game about 8 times. 100% also including upgrading ALL your skills (which again, a lot of games don't allow you to do that as well) collecting all the dolls from mini-games and books as well. In all reality, this game is very small, but it packs so much awesomeness that it's forgiveable.Becoming evil allows you to grow horns and have flies hanging around you 24/7. As fun as being evil can be, I'm not a big fan of the hairloss. Being good looks awesome as well, having a halo and a blue light surrounding you is nice. Speaking of which, tattoos and beards! These actually effect you in a big way. If you have that scary tattoo, you'll have the females and males yelping and bolting out of the sigh of your presence. Having a nice hair and stache and the ladies and gents will dig you, a lot. Sexual orientation is really awesome as well. You can really be  who you want..minus a female because you have to be a male in this game.Honestly, I could speak of how wonderful this game is for hours. It's just..for me, that game that I'll always be able to recommend and talk about. It's just a great experience and if you have a little over half a day or need to pull an allnight for whatever reason. Make this your go to game and go slave some balvarians and win the arena! Do yourself a favor and check this game out.

Posted: October 10, 2015
												Played this game a lot on the old Xbox, and got this for nostalgia's sake just recently, and I'd have to say that it still holds up pretty well.  Sure, Fable has problems. It was not the game that was promised, and some of the respawns between maps are irritating in the extreme... but there's a lot of good old-school action-adventure stuff in here.Three hours into the Steam version, and I've had no crashes or save/load problems (there were a few with the Xbox version) and I've not noticed any annoying glitches yet. If you enjoyed the original on Xbox and are thinking about this one, I can recommend it.  If you're just looking for a casual RPG/Adventure/Combat game and don't mind the dated (but still quite nice) graphics, then I'd also recommend it.This is a love-it or hate-it game, with its roots firmly back in the days when they didn't make such games too easy. Think of it as a bit like Overlord (without the minions) and you might be on more-or-less the right track.

Posted: June 22, 2014
												JUST TO CLARIFY: I have played the Fable series for a long time on the Xbox, ever since it first came out. So my hours don't really reflect how much I have played Fable, let alone the other Fable games (2 and 3).This game has a lot of features and memorable moments (Wont tell you them, no spoilers here). First off, as an RPG, this game balances all the different attributes of a character and how to get them very well. It has a lot of items, a lot of quests, and the main story is over 15 hours, which is a lot more than most games now. The story is also designed very well, and has many memorable moments, as well as a lot of variety in the envirenments. Over all, in a review, I would have to give this game a 9.2/10, but now that it is a very low price, I would give it a 9.7/10 as one of the best singleplayer games on steam.Summary: If you can bear with the older graphics, this game has very good gameplay, story, and has enough side quests to keep you going for hours.

Posted: December 12, 2014
												You should take my review with a big grain of salt because I was only able to play it for such a short while. But the reason for clocking out so soon was that the spinning camera angles gave me a really nasty motion sickness / migraine combo, and that means I can never go back to this game. No game has managed this spectacular feat since the 90's, so it's a huge minus in my book. Probably not a good game choice for anyone who's experienced similar problems with FPS / third person visuals. It's possible I would have endured longer in a console version, but I doubt it.In terms of gameplay, I was also immediately disappointed with... well, pretty much everything. The main character annoyed me from the start and I felt utterly disinclined to watch him grow into an even bigger bundle of annoyingness. Most importantly the hyped moral system was so blatantly black-and-white that it's just a bad joke. Seems to me there's not that much you can do to branch out from that, and I suspect the character changes would be mostly cosmetic.

												Awesome game! One of the best RPG's I've played! Character growth is the most amazing part, can't compare it to any game of this age. The only negatives could be that there are set paths to follow with a sizeable movement area, and that there is no character creation at the beginning. The character is a boy that grows into a man over the course of the game. The player can dress in whatever they so choose as to also have as many tatoo's or whatever hair style they want. This game has taken a special spot in my heart for most memorable RPG's!

Posted: March 6, 2016
												Fable is a game I've played several times, and at first I thought it was fantastic. I loved the story, the world, and it was really one of the first RPG's I really got into. I owned it on Xbox, and after losing it I thought I'd buy it again on steam. And after playing and beating Fable for the hundredth time, I've only just now began to realize this game is far from perfect.Don't get me wrong, Fable is still a good game, and decent RPG overall. The graphics hold up pretty well today, which is impressive for a game that's going on 12 years old. But that's really where Fable ends, "Good" and "Decent" The story has really weird pacing, the game's length is far from impressive, and the games lack of side quests really detract from replay value. Another thing I've come to dislike about fable is how simple it is. The game has very few deep and interesting mechanics, and some of the ones that are there are broken (ex. the morality and ageing systems)It may seem like I'm harping on it, but I would still recommend Fable to both casual gamers, and fans of action RPGs. While it may seem lack luster, Fable is still a solid experience with great combat, good characters, an interesting world to explore, and plenty of chickens to kick. It was a fantastic third person action RPG experience back in 2004, and while it has aged over the years, I think Falble is a purchase that you won't regret.

Posted: March 5, 2016
												If you enjoyed the original you'll enjoy this. Fable the lost chapters is a re-release of Fable for the oringinal xbox back in 2004. This version of the game not only brings you back to the original Albion but adds extra contant as well, The new content is as follows New Weapons, New outfits, New Jack of blades voice actor, and a continued story where the Hero takes on Jack in his dragon form. In the Oringinal, players where able to repeat the final mission again and again for there heart's content. In the lost chapters version players where stripped of that option to bring the extra story content. Even though the battle machanics are not like such others as Devil May Cry or God of War, it makes up for it being a story driven game focusing more on what the players do to change there apperance to shape the world around theme, Fable anniversy adds Xbox 360 graphics to this version but with the game crashing at a moments notice it won't be recemended here. Posted: January 7, 2016
												I remember playing Fable the lost chapters after having read in a magazine about all the cool stuff you could do. Unfortunately for me, I believed it was only for Xbox, which I didn't have at the time. I then turned my head in a Best Buy and my eyes widened. It was for Windows! I asked for it, as I was so excited. This was one of the few times my mom allowed me what I begged for. I asked if I could go to the car early just so I could look at the manual (I was that excited). As soon as I got home, I played Fable. Unfortunately, our computer's GPU could only muster the game on the lowest settings. The ground and sky was whitish (though contours of the ground were still visible). The effects were gone, and it was quite lifeless thinking back. However, what mattered at the time was the little adventure in there that I played for countless hours alongside the original Halo CE. This is a very good Action RPG. The "good and evil" aspect of it is pretty loosely tied with what actually happens or matters in the game. Whether you're good or evil matters very little beyond appearance. Personally, I consider it a classic game of it's time that's overshadowed by the pure mediocrity of it's sequels(however, fable II wasn't that awful I guess). The interface is a little limited, and suffers a bit due to it's age, however, when you're playing, who cares?It's still satisfying to shoot your overpowered (but well earned) magic, as well as swing around a weapon you just foundthat doesn't do as much damage, but just looks that cool. It's a game that accomplished what an action RPG involving a silent protagonist ( I think it would have been interesting to put in sex/race options, as building a character you identify with would be assisted by such options for some players). The writing's pretty crappy, and the world is somewhat unbelievable, but it is in that we can enjoy the camp of it. We can focus on the hilarity of quicksaving and slashing someone down in a quick strike and taking out the pretty pathetic guards that try to stop you raiding pie stores and weapon shops. There's something inherently enjoyable about that. It set the standard for me when it came to building a character in an ARPG (something that has yet to be truly exceeded, as most ones we play today are either first person, or have a preset character. You don't take the actualy character motivations seriously because the world is just too much like a storybook to care about anything more complex than a simple fight between good and evil (and there is no in between, and they treat it more like they support different football teams than a true moral dilemma). I think it's great for a first play through for both good and evil though, however I already played this years ago. Thinking about it, I wish I'd saved my money, as I don't see myself ever playing this one again. However,I don't know how well this has truly aged, or whether more seasoned RPG players will dig it. If you've never played, I'd pick this up on a sale, and give a simple, fun, immersive, and memorable playthrough. Otherwise, really think about whether you're going to play through this game again.

Posted: January 4, 2016
												Quick Review:This is the basic game I remember playing on the original XBox. Both fun and frustrating at times.Pros- Installs and launches flawlessly under Windows 7 Professional (my first concern, didn't see it addressed anywhere else)- Supports high resolution, AA, and high textures/details (just be sure to disable VSync)- No hesitations, hiccups, etc (unlike Fable Anniversary)- Has the original, cartoonish graphics that just go better with the atmosphere of the gameCons- Only (natively) supports the use of keyboard and mouse  ** You CAN get around this by using 3rd party keyboard to controller mapping (xpadder, CTK, JoyToKey, etc)- Saving is a bit screwy (I may be mis-remembering this though), see bottom of review for details- Does not have Steam Accomplishments/BadgesBottom line, pay the $10 for this version and you don't have the "better" graphics that actually make the game look worse. You won't have the slow-downs, stuttering, etc, You'll need to look into a keyboard to joystick program if you are dead set on using a gamepad, but the game is easily played with keyboard and mouse.A Note On Saving: This game has set savepoints that you must reach or your progress is lost. Examples:- Starting the Game: Finish a few quests to get Gold to purchase a gift... but if you complete only two of these quests and quit, you have to start over. You have to complete the town to get an "Autosave"- Guild Training: Go through the basics and a few tests, but don't complete the final step of getting your badge? Too bad, even if you saved mid-level, you now have to start the training over from the very beginning.Basically, you need to fully complete quests to the point that you see the words "AUTOSAVING" (or something like that) appear on screen.BUY THIS VERSION AND NOT THE ANNIVERSARY EDITION!!! This one will never be on sale, but at $10... it's a steal!

Posted: December 29, 2015
												TL;DR: Great game. However, if Steam is on sale, consider buying the Fable Anniversary edition instead if you've never played the original. Better graphics.By the time this review is written, Fable Anniversary costs about $3, while Fable TLC costs about $9.------------Fable offers much in its story and world-building. It tells you of a boy in a quest of a revenge and discovery of his family background. Fable is built upon the wondrous land of Albion, clearly inspired from medieval England with fantasy twist. With its quirky humor and distinctively English feel (from its music and architecture), Fable offers an interesting gameplay for those interested in story-driven RPGs where you can influence the world.This is the game that introduced me to the wonder of freedom of choice in RPG. Coming from playing JRPGs, I'm used to playing RPG like reading a book: following one story after another with side-stories in-between, doing errands, taking cities and NPCs in the game as it is.When I played Fable, everything changed.I can flirt with and marry townsfolks. I can steal items from shops. I can kill ordinary NPCs. I can make my fame (or infamy) not just through errands, but through little actions I did in the game. And what I did reflects on my alignment: the bad thing I do reflects on my dark side; the good thing reflects on light side. The world responds to my action. This seems to be common today, but back then in 2003 such feature is a rarity. Great game. However, if Steam is on sale, consider buying the Fable Anniversary edition instead if you've never played the original. Better graphics.

												The best Fable game in the franchise and probably one of the best RPGs I played in early childhood. I especially liked the ability to be a homosexual (despite marking the husband as my wife) considering the lack of options in games back then. Overall, this game offers a lot of side quests, weapons (no crafting), spells, and worthwhile plot that still has me in awe considering how much better Jack a villain was compared to the others in the franchise.

Posted: February 1, 2016
												Easily one of the most fun RPGs I've ever played, though not one of the most well-rounded. The gameplay is as fun now as it was when I played the original as a kid and getting a chance to run through it again was very welcomed. Coincidentally I've found since playing Dark Souls I rely a lot more on rolling. The sheer quantity of i-frames is a welcome pace step back from Dark Souls, which I consistently find myself comparing Fable and TLC to. I really think games with the depth and seriousness of Dark Souls could have come to be without the lighthearted path being laid out by the designers behind Fable. I still maintain that Fable: The Lost Chapters is the best game in the series, coming strictly from an enjoyability standpoint. What would be the point of gaming beyond that?

That was the risk of the game to give points if you are good or not.Nevertheless, it was a real pleasure to play this game, it was wonderful to see how much the developers thought about details...I played my first game as a good boy, now, I want to try to be badder !

Posted: February 19, 2016
												Great game, I have played both Anniversary and TLC.Fable I has a great storyline and is totally worth the money. It has a few bugs tho.TLC is great for the oldschool feels if you have played it before, if you haven't played it ever dont worry graphics and sound are pretty good for the release date.Now what should you pick, TLC or Anniversary?- Anniversary has controller support, mods (not alot) and updated graphics. So if you love your controller and/or have never played TLC and have the money I would recommend you Anniversary - which can be found here: - For the oldschool players around: I recommend buying TLC, you are gonne have them oldschool feels... Anniversary has some differences from TLC you might find annoying, like different faces on your favourite characters, mobs spawning in later than usual, etc.Anyway, good luck and have fun in Albion

Posted: February 5, 2016
												Fable: The Lost Chapters is a very fun fantasy RPG. You can choose to be a good or evil person and you actually age as you continue to level up your character and your age kinda shows on characters in game npc's notice it also. It has a great story to it and both main and side quests are fairly rewarding. You can choose to marry and can  you marry multiple people but not within the same town. Your character also gains fame with the more quests you complete. Overall it is just a great game.

Posted: February 16, 2016
												This game is actually brilliant. It was the first game I remember playing as a little kid and it's the one I had the most memories with. Though not completing a lot of it as a kid, I can play this game now as an adult to feel nostalgia and actually complete all of the content that I never managed to. The story isn't as good as Fable 2 in my point of view, which should definitely be on Steam. 6/10

Posted: November 26, 2016
												I nominated this game for the "Best Use Of Farm Animal" category in the Steam Awards. For my personal choice, it was between this or the Stronghold series, due to its ability to let you fling cows via catapults - however, I find that kicking chickens is a much less strenuous activity that garners a level of enjoyment near the same level, even if the townspeople call me strange names afterward.

Posted: November 27, 2016
												This is without a doubt, my favorite game of all time. Its a game that's alway shad it all for me. A nice story along with pretty good combat, as well as variance in the combat systesm. I've always loved this game, and was seriously disappointed in the sequels that I feel never measured up to the original. If you've never played this game, I highly recommend you do because even to this day it's a great game.

Posted: November 27, 2016
												Fable-Lost chapters is one of the best games, possibly my favorite game i've ever played. there is such a great story, and i played countless playthroughs on the xbox. Now on pc it's the same story, great  environment, and a smooth 100hz locked in 2k makes this game suprisingly smooth and full of color, they allow for 8x anti aliasing, and since this game isn't very graphically demanding, everything just goes together really well. I like to play through this game for time to time, wonderful purchase. Get this version, not the remake.

Posted: November 26, 2016
												I've played this game so many times, on a few different platforms, from a few different iterations.  Although this isn't my favorite version of the game, it is still Fable, and as such deserves the time and patience I originally devoted to it.  I highly recommend it to any new RPG gamer.  Who knows, it may become your favorite too.

Posted: November 26, 2016
												Lionhead Studios tried, and subsequently failed to a higher degree with each attempt, to recapture the charm and playability of Fable: The Lost Chapters. The first, and the best of the Fable series, this is a game that still holds up today and is every bit as magical as playing it all those years ago. Grab this version instead of the cashgrab remaster - benefits of doing this include receiving all the content you pay for as opposed to in game content being locked away as DLC. The gameplay, music, and story are all great, but the atmosphere is like no other. I highly recommend this game.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												This was the very first action-RPG I ever played back in the original Xbox. It was the first introduction I had not only to the genre, but the medieval fantasy genre as a whole. This game shaped me into what I am today. My love of everything fantasy, RPGs, and of course, British humor, stems from this game. Fable TLC stands the test of time, and every time I play it it's like going back again.
